{{Infobox officeholder |name = Jay Inslee |image = Jay Inslee official portrait.jpg |order = 23rd [[List of Governors of Washington|Governor of Washington]] |lieutenant = [[Brad Owen]]
[[Cyrus Habib]] |term_start = January 16, 2013 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Christine Gregoire]] |successor = |state1 = [[Washington (state)|Washington]] |district1 = {{ushr|WA|1|1st}} |term_start1 = January 3, 1999 |term_end1 = March 20, 2012 |predecessor1 = [[Rick White (politician)|Rick White]] |successor1 = [[Suzan DelBene]] |state2 = [[Washington (state)|Washington]] |district2 = {{ushr|WA|4|4th}} |term_start2 = January 3, 1993 |term_end2 = January 3, 1995 |predecessor2 = [[Sid Morrison]] |successor2 = [[Doc Hastings]] |state_house3 = Washington |district3 = [[Washington's 14th legislative district|14th legislative]] |term_start3 = January 9, 1989 |term_end3 = January 11, 1993 |predecessor3 = Jim Lewis |successor3 = Dave Lemmon |birth_name = Jay Robert Inslee |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1951|2|9}} |birth_place = [[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |residence = [[Washington Governor's Mansion|Governor's Mansion]] |spouse = {{marriage|Trudi Inslee|1972}} |children = 3 |education = [[University of Washington]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[Willamette University]] ([[Juris Doctor|JD]]) }} '''Jay Robert Inslee''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɪ|n|z|l|iː}}; born February 9, 1951) is an American [[politician]], author, and attorney who is the 23rd [[List of Governors of Washington|Governor of Washington]], elected in 2012. Inslee is a member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]. Born in [[Seattle]], Inslee graduated from the [[University of Washington]] and [[Willamette University College of Law]]. He served in the [[Washington House of Representatives]] from 1989 to 1993. Inslee represented {{ushr|WA|4}}, which included parts of the state around [[Yakima, Washington|Yakima]], in the [[United States House of Representatives]] from 1993 to 1995. Defeated for re-election in [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1994|1994]], Inslee returned to private practice and then ran for governor of Washington in the [[Washington gubernatorial election, 1996|1996 election]], coming in fifth in the [[blanket primary]] ahead of the general election, which was won by Democrat [[Gary Locke]]. Inslee then served as regional director for the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services]] under [[President of the United States|President]] [[Bill Clinton]]. Inslee was elected back to the U.S. House of Representatives in 1998, this time for {{ushr|WA|1|}}, which included Seattle's northern suburbs in [[King County, Washington|King County]], [[Snohomish County, Washington|Snohomish County]] and [[Kitsap County, Washington|Kitsap County]]. He was reelected six times before announcing that he was running for Governor of Washington again on June 27, 2011. He resigned from Congress on March 20, 2012, to focus on his campaign. He defeated Republican [[Rob McKenna]], the [[List of Attorneys General of Washington|Attorney General of Washington]], in [[Washington gubernatorial election, 2012|the general election]], 52% to 48%. Inslee was [[Washington gubernatorial election, 2016|reelected]] to a second term in 2016, defeating Republican [[Port of Seattle|Seattle Port Commissioner]] [[Bill Bryant (politician)|Bill Bryant]], 54% to 46%. Inslee has emerged as one of the most recognized [[Protests against Donald Trump|critics]] of the administration of President [[Donald Trump]]. Alongside State Solicitor General [[Noah Purcell]] and State Attorney General [[Bob Ferguson (politician)|Bob Ferguson]], Inslee played a major role in [[Washington v. Trump|the opposition to]] Trump's [[Executive Order 13769]], in which a restriction halted travel for 90 days from seven Muslim-majority countries, and a total ban on Syrian refugees entering the United States. The order was blocked by the courts and later superseded by other executive orders. Inslee served as chair of the [[Democratic Governors Association]] for the [[United States gubernatorial elections, 2018|2018 election cycle]]. ==Early life, education, and law career== Inslee was born in Seattle, the son of Adele A. (née Brown), a sales clerk, and Frank E. Inslee, a teacher and coach.{{cite web|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~battle/reps/inslee.htm |title=inslee |publisher=Freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-11}} He graduated from Seattle's [[Ingraham High School]], the [[University of Washington]] ([[Bachelor of Arts]], [[Economics]]), and [[Willamette University College of Law]] ([[Juris Doctor]]). Inslee has attributed his interest in the outdoors to the years his parents spent leading student groups on wilderness conservation trips in cooperation with the SCA in [[Mount Rainier]] in the 1960s and 1970s.[http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2003598649_aliciacol03.html Putting Parents Before Pollsters], Alicia Mundy, May 9, 2007 He practiced law for 10 years in [[Selah, Washington]], a city just north of [[Yakima, Washington|Yakima]]. ==Washington House of Representatives (1989–1993)== ===Elections=== Inslee ran for the [[Washington House of Representatives]] in 1988 after incumbent Republican State Representative Jim Lewis resigned to become political commentator of a Yakima television station.https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Om8hAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_IcFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2144,1755845&dq=jay+inslee&hl=en He was inspired to run after the state legislature undermined a school bond that he had worked to pass after years of failure.[http://www.vote-smart.org/bio.php?can_id=27125 PVS Biography]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. In the blanket primary, Republican Lynn Carmichael ranked first with 43% and Inslee ranked second with 40%. Republican Glen Blomgren ranked third with 17%.{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=533647 |title=WA State House District 14 Seat 2 - Blanket Primary Race - Sep 20, 1988 |publisher=Our Campaigns |date= |accessdate=2012-09-11}} In the general election, Inslee defeated Carmichael 52%-48%.{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=407097 |title=WA State House District 14 Seat 2 Race - Nov 08, 1988 |publisher=Our Campaigns |date= |accessdate=2012-09-11}} In 1990, Inslee won re-election with 62% of the vote.{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=325303 |title=WA State House District 14 Seat 2 Race - Nov 06, 1990 |publisher=Our Campaigns |date= |accessdate=2012-09-11}} ===Tenure=== In the Washington state legislature, Inslee pursued a bill to provide initial funding to build five branch campuses of the [[Washington State University]] system. Although the bill failed, Inslee's tenacity made an impression on House Speaker Joe King, who said: "He's not afraid to incur the wrath of the speaker or the caucus."Yakima Herald-Republic, June 11, 1989. In 1991, Inslee voted for a state energy policy which required the state to devise a cost-effective energy strategy, and also that state agencies and school districts must pursue and maintain energy-efficient operation of their facilities.HB 1022 - An act relating to state energy policy. Retrieved from http://apps.leg.wa.gov/documents/WSLdocs/1991-92/Htm/Bill%20Reports/House/1022.HBR.htm{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. ===Committee assignments=== He served on the Higher Education and Housing Committees.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4YxfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9i8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=3090,5038870&dq=jay+inslee&hl=en|title=Lewiston Morning Tribune - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com}}{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=oaJUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=G48DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6070,4754598&dq=jay+inslee&hl=en|title=Ellensburg Daily Record - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com}} ==U.S. House of Representatives (1993–1995)== [[File:Inslees and the Dalai Lama.jpg|thumb|Jay Inslee and his wife Trudi Inslee meet with the [[14th Dalai Lama|Dalai Lama]].]] ===Elections=== ;1992 :In 1992, he ran for and was elected to the [[United States Congress]] representing {{ushr|Washington|4}} in the central-eastern part of the state. His home area of the district, anchored by Yakima, is relatively rural and agriculture-based, while the southeastern part of his district is more focused on research and nuclear waste disposal, anchored by the [[Tri-Cities, Washington|Tri-Cities]]. ;1994 :He lost his bid for re-election in the [[Republican Revolution]] of 1994 in a rematch against his 1992 opponent, [[Doc Hastings]]. Inslee attributed his 1994 defeat in large part to his vote for the [[Federal Assault Weapons Ban]].{{cite news|last=Postman, Sorrano|first=David, Barbara|title=Former Rep. Jay Inslee Joins Governor's Race|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19951129&slug=2155065|accessdate=30 June 2011|newspaper=Seattle Times|date=November 29, 1995}} ===Tenure=== In Congress Inslee passed the Yakima River Enhancement Act,[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/D?c103:1:./temp/~c103ykeHzS:THOMAS.gov HR 1690, 103rd Congress], Library of Congress bill page. a bill long held up in Congress by brokering a breakthrough with irrigators and wildlife advocates. He also helped to open Japanese markets to American apples, and fund and oversee the nation's biggest nuclear waste site at the [[Hanford Site|Hanford Nuclear Reservation]] near [[Richland, Washington]].[http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19960903&slug=2347250 Inslee Sticks To Campaign Game Plan -- Message Attempts To Boost His Profile], Sept 3, 1996. ===Committee assignments=== [[File:Repinslee.jpg|thumb|left|Early portrait of Inslee]]In his first congressional tenure, he was placed on the [[U.S. House Committee on Agriculture]] to protect the district's rural areas and the [[United States House Committee on Science, Space and Technology|U.S. House Committee on Science, Space and Technology]] to protect the [[Hanford Reservation]].{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GVdUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EI8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6322,438162&dq=jay+inslee+committee&hl=en|title=Ellensburg Daily Record - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com}} ==Inter-congressional years (1995–1999)== Inslee moved to [[Bainbridge Island]], a suburb of [[Seattle]], and briefly resumed the practice of law. ===1996 gubernatorial election=== {{Main|Washington gubernatorial election, 1996}} He ran for [[Governor of Washington]] in [[Washington gubernatorial election, 1996|1996]] and lost in the [[blanket primary]]. Democratic [[King County Executive]] and former State Representative [[Gary Locke]] ranked first with 24% of the vote. Democratic [[Mayor of Seattle]] [[Norm Rice]] ranked second with 18%, but didn't qualify for the general election. Republican State Senator [[Ellen Craswell]] ranked third with 15%, and became the Republican candidate to qualify for the general election. Republican State Senator and Senate Majority Leader [[Dale Foreman]] ranked fourth with 13%. Inslee ranked fifth with 10%. No other candidate on the ballot received double digits.{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=18378 |title=WA Governor - All Party Primary Race - Sep 17, 1996 |publisher=Our Campaigns |date= |accessdate=2012-09-11}} ===Clinton administration=== After Inslee's failed 1996 bid for [[Governor of Washington]], [[President of the United States]] [[Bill Clinton]] appointed him regional director for the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services]]. ==U.S. House of Representatives (1999–2012)== ===Elections=== [[File:Jay Inslee, Official Portrait, c112th Congress.jpg|thumb|Inslee as a representative]] Inslee ran again for Congress in 1998, this time in the 1st congressional district against two-term incumbent [[Rick White (politician)|Rick White]]. His campaign attracted national attention when he became the first Democratic candidate to air television ads attacking his opponent and the Republican congressional leadership for the [[Lewinsky scandal]].[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/clinton/stories/campaign101198.htm Candidates Are Held Hostage by Scandal], Washington Post, October 11, 1998. Inslee won with 49.8% of the vote to White's 44.1%; he had an unintentional assist in his successful return by the conservative [[third political party]] candidacy of Bruce Craswell, husband of 1996 GOP gubernatorial nominee [[Ellen Craswell]]. The 1st was a swing district for most of the 1990s; Inslee's win marked the third time the district had changed hands in four elections. However, Inslee was a major beneficiary of the recent Democratic trend in the Seattle area. Inslee defeated [[Washington Senate]] Minority Leader Dan McDonald in 2000, taking 54.6% of the vote. Inslee defeated former state representative Joe Marine in 2002, taking 55.6% of the vote after the district was made more Democratic in the 2000s round of redistricting. He would never face another contest nearly that close, and was reelected three more times with over 60 percent of the vote. In July 2003, after [[Gary Locke]] announced he would not seek a third term as Washington's governor, Inslee briefly flirted with a gubernatorial bid before deciding to remain in Congress.[http://www.seattlepi.com/local/138758_governor09.html Inslee Won't Run For Governor], Joel Connelly, Seattle Post Intelligencer, September 8, 2003. During the 2009-10 campaign cycle, Inslee raised $1,140,025. In data compiled for the period 2005 to 2007 and excluding individual contributions of less than $200, 64 percent of Inslee's donations were from outside the state of Washington and 86 percent came from outside his district (compared to 79 percent for the average House member). 43 percent of Inslee's donations came from Washington, D.C., Virginia and Maryland. The largest interests funding Inslee's campaign were pharmaceutical and health related companies, lawyers and law firms, and high tech companies.{{cite web|title=Campaign Funding Sources|url=http://maplight.org/us-congress/legislator/297-jay-inslee|work=Inslee Contributions Illuminated|publisher=maplight.org|accessdate=30 June 2011}} In 2010 he won by a 15-point margin, with 57.67% of the votes cast in his favor.{{cite web|last=Reed|first=Sam|title=Congressional District 1|url=http://vote.wa.gov/Elections/WEI/Results.aspx?ElectionID=37&JurisdictionTypeID=3&JurisdictionID=103&ViewMode=Results|work=2010 Election Results|publisher=Washington Secretary of State|accessdate=29 June 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110321001943/http://vote.wa.gov/Elections/WEI/Results.aspx?ElectionID=37&JurisdictionTypeID=3&JurisdictionID=103&ViewMode=Results|archivedate=21 March 2011|df=}} His district went 62% to [[Barack Obama]] in 2008, an indication of how strongly the district then leaned Democratic. ===Tenure=== Though a member of the [[Bill Clinton]] [[New Democrat Coalition]],[http://www.house.gov/tauscher/ndc/membership.shtml New Democrat Coalition membership] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060130091403/http://www.house.gov/tauscher/ndc/membership.shtml |date=2006-01-30 }} Inslee has accumulated a [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberal]] voting record and expertise on high-tech issues.{{cite web|url=http://blog.seattletimes.nwsource.com/techtracks/archives/2007/03/inslee_bill_would_push_fcc_on_white_space_decision.html|title=The Seattle Times: Tech Tracks|work=nwsource.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071118135626/http://blog.seattletimes.nwsource.com/techtracks/archives/2007/03/inslee_bill_would_push_fcc_on_white_space_decision.html|archivedate=2007-11-18|df=}} Inslee was awarded a "Friend of the National Parks" award by the [[National Parks Conservation Association]] (NPCA) in 2001 for his support of legislation protecting the integrity and quality of the [[National Park System]].[http://www.npca.org/media_center/press_releases/2001/page-27598936.html Friend of the National Parks Award Winners] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121111738/http://www.npca.org/media_center/press_releases/2001/page-27598936.html |date=2008-11-21 }}, [[National Parks Conservation Association]], February 15, 2001 Inslee was "... one of Congress's most ardent advocates of strong action to combat global warming," according to ''[[The New York Times]]''.{{cite news |title=At House E.P.A. Hearing, Both Sides Claim Science |last=Broder |first=John M. |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/09/science/earth/09climate.html |date=March 9, 2011 |page=17 |accessdate=January 22, 2017}} Inslee was the first public figure to propose an Apollo-like energy program with an opinion editorial in the ''[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]'', on December 19, 2002,{{cite web|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/opinion/100516_inslee19.shtml|title=New Apollo Project can help us unplug our need for oil|work=seattlepi.com}} and in a series of similar pieces in other publications. Inslee co-authored ''[[Apollo's Fire (book)|Apollo's Fire: Igniting America's Clean Energy Economy]]'', in which he argues that through improved Federal policies the United States can wean itself off of its dependence on foreign oil and [[fossil fuel]], create millions of [[Green-collar worker]] jobs, and stop [[global warming]]. He has been a prominent supporter of the [[Apollo Alliance]].[http://www.apolloalliance.org/resources_100mpg.php Inslee articles at the Apollo Alliance web page] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081126233311/http://www.apolloalliance.org/resources_100mpg.php |date=2008-11-26 }} Inslee strongly believes the [[Environmental Protection Agency]] should remain authorized to regulate [[greenhouse gas]] emissions. In a 2011 House hearing on the [[Energy Tax Prevention Act]], Inslee said Republicans have "an allergy to science and scientists," during a discussion of whether the [[Regulation of greenhouse gases under the Clean Air Act]] should remain in place following a controversial court finding on the issue.{{cite news|last=Wing|first=Nick|title=Jay Inslee: Republicans Suffer From 'Allergy To Science And Scientists'|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/09/jay-inslee-gop-allergy-science_n_833404.html|work=Huffpost Politics|publisher=The Huffington Post|accessdate=1 July 2011|date=March 9, 2011}} He has been an outspoken critic of the [[George W. Bush]] administration's decision to [[2003 invasion of Iraq]]. On July 31, 2007, Inslee introduced legislation that called for an inquiry to determine whether then [[United States Attorney General]] [[Alberto Gonzales]] should be impeached. Gonzales eventually resigned.[[Associated Press]], [http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/politics/la-na-impeach1aug01,1,130274.story?coll=la-news-politics-national&track=crosspromo ''Bill calls for Gonzales impeachment inquiry''], [[Los Angeles Times]], August 1, 2007 Inslee voted for the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]], the federal health care law.http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2010/roll165.xml In 2011, Inslee voted in favor of authorizing the use of U.S. armed forces in the [[2011 Libyan civil war]] and voted against limiting the use of funds to support [[NATO]]'s [[2011 military intervention in Libya]].{{cite web|title=Congress Votes on Libya|url=http://www.opencongress.org/people/show/400193_jay_inslee|work=Inslee Supports Adventure in Libya|publisher=OpenCongress.org|accessdate=1 July 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110701094839/http://www.opencongress.org/people/show/400193_Jay_Inslee|archivedate=1 July 2011|df=}} Inslee was once touted as a candidate for [[United States Secretary of the Interior]] and for [[United States Secretary of Energy]] during the [[Presidential transition of Barack Obama]].[http://blog.seattletimes.nwsource.com/politicsnorthwest/2008/10/31/inslee_for_interior_secretary.html Inslee For Interior Secretary?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090126133645/http://blog.seattletimes.nwsource.com/politicsnorthwest/2008/10/31/inslee_for_interior_secretary.html|date=2009-01-26}} Seattle Times, October 31, 2008[http://newsweek.washingtonpost.com/postglobal/energywire/2008/11/obamas_energy_department.html Obama's Energy Department] Newsweek/Washington Post EnergyWire, Steve Mufson, November 6, 2008 On March 20, 2012, Inslee left Congress to focus on his campaign for Governor of Washington.{{cite news|last=Grygiel|first=Chris|title=US Resp. Inslee to resign for Wash. gov. race|url=http://www.thenewstribune.com/2012/03/10/2061446/ap-sources-wash-rep-inslee-to.html|newspaper=The News Tribune|date=March 10, 2012|agency=Associated Press}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ===Committee assignments=== *'''[[United States House Committee on Energy and Commerce]]''' **[[United States House Energy Subcommittee on Energy and Power]] ===Caucus memberships=== *Congressional Friends of Animals Caucus *Congressional Internet Caucus *House Medicare and Medicaid Fairness Caucus *House Oceans Caucus *[[United States Congressional International Conservation Caucus]] *Congressional Arts Caucus ==Governor of Washington (2013–present)== ===2012 gubernatorial election=== {{Main|Washington gubernatorial election, 2012}} On June 27, 2011, Inslee announced his candidacy for Governor of Washington in 2012.[http://kuow.org/program.php?id=23805 Inslee Announces Run For Governor] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111015020823/http://kuow.org/program.php?id=23805 |date=2011-10-15 }}, Liz Jones, KUOW, June 28, 2011. His campaign focused on job creation, outlining dozens of proposals to increase job growth in clean energy, the aerospace industry, and biotechnology. He also supported a ballot measure to legalize gay marriage, which passed, and opposed tax increases.[http://seattletimes.com/html/localnews/2019621861_elexgovernor07m.html Inslee takes strong lead, but McKenna won't concede], Jim Brunner, Seattle Times, 7 November 2012. He won election by a relatively slim three-point margin over his Republican opponent, [[Rob McKenna]], with 51% of the vote.{{cite web|last=Reed|first=Sam|title=WA STATE Gubernatorial results|url=http://sos.wa.gov|publisher=WA STATE SEC OF STATE|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130223191448/http://sos.wa.gov/|archivedate=2013-02-23|df=}} ===2016 gubernatorial election=== {{main|Washington gubernatorial election, 2016}} On November 8, 2016, Inslee won re-election as Governor of Washington, defeating Republican former Port of Seattle Commissioner Bill Bryant, 54–46%. === First term: 2013–2017 === During the 2013 session, the [[Washington State Legislature|legislature]] failed to create a fiscal budget plan during the initial session, and Inslee was forced to call two special sessions in order to give time for a budget to be created. The [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]]-controlled [[Washington State Senate|Senate]] and the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]]-controlled [[Washington State House of Representatives|House]] each passed their own budgets, but could not agree with one.{{cite news|title=Washington Gov. Jay Inslee calls second special session|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/politics/index.ssf/2013/06/washington_gov_jay_inslee_call_1.html|newspaper=Oregon Live|date=June 11, 2013}} Finally, in June 2013, Inslee was able to sign a US$33.6 billion budget upon which both houses had agreed as a compromise, albeit hesitantly.{{cite news|last=La Corte|first=Rachel|title=Gov. Inslee signs $33.6 billion state budget|url=http://www.kirotv.com/news/news/inslee-signs-336-billion-state-budget/nYZn8/|newspaper=Kirotv|date=June 30, 2013}} On June 13, 2013, Inslee signed an additional [[estate tax]] into law. The estate tax had bipartisan support, and passed the Senate in a 30–19 vote.{{cite news|title=Washington Gov. Jay Inslee signs estate tax fix into law|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/politics/index.ssf/2013/06/washington_gov_jay_inslee_sign.html|newspaper=Oregon Live|date=June 13, 2013}} [[File:Jay Inslee Speech (8724201105).jpg|thumb|left|Inslee giving a speech in May 2013]] In December 2013, Inslee was elected to serve as finance chair of the [[Democratic Governors Association]].{{cite web|last=Burns|first=Alexander|title=DGA appoints leaders for 2014|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/12/dga-appoints-leaders-for-2014-100877.html?hp=f1|publisher=Politico|accessdate=2013-12-09}} In January 2014, Inslee gave a speech commending machinists who voted to renew [[Boeing]]'s contract with Seattle, allowing the company to build its [[Boeing 777#777X Program|Boeing 777x]] aircraft in Seattle. Inslee said the contract would bring Washington to a new industrial plateau and be a turning point for Washington jobs:
These jobs are in the thousands and it is not only on the 777X, the first model of the 777X but all the subsequent derivative models as well.
The plan was to prevent Boeing from building part of the aircraft in Washington and part of it somewhere else, as they had done with the [[Boeing 787]], which had been partially constructed in [[South Carolina]].{{cite news|last=Kim|first=Hana|title=Governor Inslee says Boeing deal could open new industrial plateau|url=http://q13fox.com/2014/01/04/governor-inslee-says-boeing-deal-could-open-new-industrial-plateau/#axzz2pVAPMUv4|newspaper=Q13 Fox|date=January 4, 2014}}{{cite news|title=Boeing pact with Machinists union called turning point for labor|url=http://triblive.com/business/headlines/5360816-74/boeing-union-state#axzz2pVAQFg9d|newspaper=TribLive|date=January 4, 2014}} On 11 February 2014, Inslee announced that he was issuing a [[Moratorium (law)|moratorium]] on [[Capital punishment in Washington state|executions in Washington]]:
There have been too many doubts raised about capital punishment, there are too many flaws in this system today. There is too much at stake to accept an imperfect system.
Inslee cited the high cost of pursuing the death penalty, the randomness with which it was sought, and a lack of evidence that it is a deterrent.{{cite news|title=Inslee halts executions in state while he is governor|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/localnews/2022883256_deathpenaltyinsleexml.html|newspaper=The Seattle Times|date=February 11, 2014|accessdate=2014-02-12}}{{cite news|title=Washington state to suspend death penalty by governor's moratorium|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/feb/11/washington-state-death-penalty-governor-inslee-suspends|newspaper=The Guardian|date=February 11, 2014|accessdate=2014-02-12}} === Second term: 2017–present === Inslee began his second term in January 2017, proposing full funding of state education (in compliance with the [[McCleary decision]]) and addressing mental health needs, while also raising worker pay.{{cite news |last=O'Sullivan |first=Joseph |date=January 9, 2017 |title=State lawmakers face tough fight over education funding as legislative session opens |page=B1 |url=http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/state-lawmakers-face-tough-fight-over-education-funding-as-legislative-session-opens/ |work=The Seattle Times |accessdate=February 21, 2017}} After newly inaugurated President [[Donald Trump]] on January 27 signed an [[Executive Order 13769|executive order to ban entry from Muslim countries]], Inslee and Attorney General [[Bob Ferguson (politician)|Bob Ferguson]] announced their intention to sue Trump, alleging his order was unconstitutional. The civil action, ''[[Washington v. Trump]]'', was filed on January 30 and on February 3 successfully earned a [[temporary restraining order]] to forbid federal enforcement of certain provisions of the order.{{cite news |last=Burns |first=Alexander |date=January 30, 2017 |title=Legal Challenges Mount Against Trump's Travel Ban |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/30/us/legal-challenges-mount-against-trumps-travel-ban.html?_r=0 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=February 21, 2017}}{{cite news |last=Burns |first=Alexander |date=February 4, 2017 |title=How Washington State Upended Trump's Travel Ban |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/04/us/trump-travel-ban-washington-seattle-ferguson.html |work=The New York Times |accessdate=February 21, 2017}} An appeal and request to stay filed by the federal government was subsequently denied by the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit]]. Inslee and Ferguson declared their victory over President Trump on February 16, after his administration announced they would revise their travel ban to comply with the court decisions.{{cite news |last1=Dolan |first1=Maura |last2=Kaleem |first2=Jaweed |date=February 16, 2017 |title=Trump says he will issue a new order after a 'very bad decision' blocked his initial travel ban |url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-travel-executive-order-20170216-story.html |work=The Los Angeles Times |accessdate=February 21, 2017}} Inslee garnered national media attention during the lawsuit,{{cite news |last=Wang |first=Amy B. |date=February 5, 2017 |title=How Washington state became the epicenter of resistance to Trump's agenda |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/02/05/how-washington-state-became-the-epicenter-of-resistance-to-trumps-agenda/ |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=February 21, 2017}} fueling speculation from ''[[The Seattle Times]]'' that he might run for president during the [[United States presidential election, 2020|2020 election]].{{cite news |last=Brunner |first=Jim |date=February 21, 2017 |title=Jay Inslee for president? Governor's profile is on the rise |url=http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/inslees-profile-lifted-with-states-legal-victories-on-immigration/ |work=The Seattle Times |accessdate=February 21, 2017}} During the beginning of his second term, Inslee awarded $6.4 million in grant funding to create apprenticeships and career connections for 29,000 youth in 11 communities{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/wagovernor/inslee-awards-6-4-129c4de96df3|title=Inslee awards $6 million to create apprenticeship and career connections for 29,000 youth in 11 communities|last=|first=|date=|website=Medium|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}. Inslee called this new initiative [https://careerconnectwa.org/ Career Connect Washington], which includes a Task Force{{Cite web|url=http://www.wtb.wa.gov/careerconnectwa.asp|title=Career Connected Washington Task Force|last=|first=|date=|website=Workforce Training & Education Board|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} and several prominent stakeholder groups including [[Alaska Airlines|Alaska Airline]], [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]], [[Boeing]], [[Microsoft]], and [[Kaiser Permanente]]. As a result of Career Connect Washington, new apprenticeship opportunities have been established{{Cite news|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/washington-voters-dont-think-schools-prepare-kids-for-careers-the-state-is-trying-to-change-that/|title=Washington voters don’t think schools prepare kids for careers. The state is trying to change that.|date=2018-10-31|work=The Seattle Times|access-date=2018-11-16|language=en-US}} including the [https://www.thenewstribune.com/news/local/education/article143777889.html Aerospace Joint Apprenticeship Committee]'s registered Youth Apprenticeship{{Citation|title=Apprenticeship|date=2018-11-16|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apprenticeship&oldid=869164946|work=Wikipedia|language=en|access-date=2018-11-16}} program for high school students. Inslee will serve as chair of the [[Democratic Governors Association]] for the [[United States gubernatorial elections, 2018|2018 election cycle]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.mycolumbiabasin.com/2017/12/04/washington-governor-elected-next-dga-chair/|title=Washington governor elected next DGA chair|date=2017-12-04|work=My Columbia Basin|access-date=2017-12-05|language=en-US}} ==Electoral history== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date || Position || Status || Opponent || Result || Vote share || Opponent vote share |- | 1988 || WA Representative || || || Elected || || |- | 1990 || WA Representative || Incumbent || || Re-elected || || |- | 1992 || U.S. Representative || Open seat || [[Doc Hastings]] (R) || Elected || 51% || 49% |- | 1994 || U.S. Representative || Incumbent || [[Doc Hastings]] (R) || Defeated || 47% || 53% |- | 1996 || WA Governor || Open seat primary || [[Gary Locke]] (D), others || Defeated || || |- | 1998 || U.S. Representative || Challenger || [[Rick White (politician)|Rick White]] (R) || Elected || 50% || 44% |- | 2000 || U.S. Representative || Incumbent || Dan McDonald (R) || Re-elected || 55% || 43% |- | 2002 || U.S. Representative || Incumbent || Joe Marine (R) || Re-elected || 56% || 41% |- | 2004 || U.S. Representative || Incumbent || Randy Eastwood (R) || Re-elected || 62% || 36% |- | 2006 || U.S. Representative || Incumbent || Larry W. Ishmael (R) || Re-elected || 68% || 32% |- | 2008 || U.S. Representative || Incumbent || Larry W. Ishmael (R) || Re-elected || 68% || 32% |- | 2010 || U.S. Representative || Incumbent || James Watkins (R) || Re-elected || 57% || 43% |- | 2012 || WA Governor || Open seat || [[Rob McKenna]] (R) || Elected || 51% || 49% |- | 2016 || WA Governor || Incumbent || [[Bill Bryant (politician)|Bill Bryant]] (R) || Re-elected || 54% ||46% |} ==Personal life== [[File:Trudi Inslee 02.jpg|thumb|150px|Trudi Inslee]] Inslee and his wife Trudi were high school sweethearts, and were married on August 27, 1972. They have three sons, Jack, Connor, and Joe, and live on [[Bainbridge Island]].[http://www.jayinslee.com/index.php?page=display&id=1 Biography Page] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081106045724/http://www.jayinslee.com/index.php?page=display&id=1 |date=2008-11-06 }}. Inslee is an avid basketball player and a member of "Hoopaholics",[http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/highschoolsports/2003867146_flashback04.html "Flashback | Political football now Inslee's game], Seattle Times, Sept. 4, 2007. a charity group dedicated to "treatment of old guys addicted to basketball and who can no longer jump" as Inslee has often joked. In October 2009, he played basketball at the White House in a series of games featuring members of Congress on one team and members of the administration, including President Obama, on the other.{{cite news|last=Daly |first=Matthew |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2010027342_apusobamabasketballcongress.html |title=Local News | Lawmakers play hoops with Obama at White House | Seattle Times Newspaper |publisher=Seattletimes.nwsource.com |date=2009-10-08 |accessdate=2010-08-29}} ==Works== *Jay Inslee and Bracken Hendricks, ''Apollo's Fire: Igniting America's Clean Energy Economy'', Island Press (October 1, 2007), {{ISBN|978-1-59726-175-3}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[http://www.governor.wa.gov/ Governor Jay Inslee] official government site *{{Dmoz|Regional/North_America/United_States/Washington/Government/Executive/Governor_Jay_Inslee}} *[http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=I000026 Profile] at the ''[[Biographical Directory of the United States Congress]]'' *{{C-SPAN|jayinslee}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{s-bef|before=[[Sid Morrison]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Member of the [[List of United States Representatives from Washington|U.S. House of Representatives]]
from [[Washington's 4th congressional district]]|years=1993–1995}} {{s-aft|after=[[Doc Hastings]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Rick White (politician)|Rick White]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Member of the [[List of United States Representatives from Washington|U.S. House of Representatives]]
from [[Washington's 1st congressional district]]|years=1999–2012}} {{s-aft|after=[[Suzan DelBene]]}} |- {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=[[Christine Gregoire]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] nominee for [[List of Governors of Washington|Governor of Washington]]|years=[[Washington gubernatorial election, 2012|2012]], [[Washington gubernatorial election, 2016|2016]]}} {{s-inc|recent}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Dannel Malloy|Dan Malloy]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Chair of the [[Democratic Governors Association]]|years=2017–2018}} {{s-aft|after=[[Gina Raimondo]]}} |- {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Christine Gregoire]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Governor of Washington]]|years=2013–present}} {{s-inc}} |- {{s-prec|usa}} {{s-bef|before={{Incumbent VPOTUS}}|as=[[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]]|rows=2}} {{s-ttl|title=[[United States order of precedence|Order of Precedence of the United States]]|years=Within Washington|rows=2}} {{s-aft|after=Mayor of city
in which event is held}} |- {{s-aft|after=Otherwise {{Incumbent U.S. House Speaker}}
{{nowrap|''as [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives]]}}''}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Steve Bullock (American politician)|Steve Bullock]]|as=[[Governor of Montana]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[United States order of precedence|Order of Precedence of the United States]]|years=Outside Washington}} {{s-aft|after=[[Butch Otter]]|as=[[Governor of Idaho]]}} {{s-end}} {{Governors of Washington}} {{Current U.S. governors}} {{Current statewide political officials of Washington}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Inslee, Jay}} [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:21st-century American politicians]] [[Category:American chief executives]] [[Category:American Protestants]] [[Category:Democratic Party members of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:Democratic Party state governors of the United States]] [[Category:Governors of Washington (state)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from Washington (state)]] [[Category:Members of the Washington House of Representatives]] [[Category:People associated with energy]] [[Category:Politicians from Seattle]] [[Category:University of Washington alumni]] [[Category:Washington (state) Democrats]] [[Category:Washington (state) lawyers]] [[Category:Willamette University College of Law alumni]]

The family [[Clusiaceae]] was divided by [[Cronquist system|Cronquist]] into 2 [[subfamily|subfamilies]]: the Clusioideae (typical subfamily) and the Hypericoideae. The latter was often treated as a family - the '''Hypericaceae''' or '''St. John's wort family'''. Elements of the Hypericoideae are more common in North [[temperate]] areas and those of the Clusioideae are centered in the [[Tropics]].
Later classifications however divide the family in a finer way. The [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomy]] below mostly follows that of Stevens.<ref>Stevens, P. F. (1980). A revision of the Old World species of Calophyllum (Guttiferae). ''J. Arnold Arboretum'' 61:117–699.</ref> Molecular studies have shown that the family [[Podostemaceae]] - the riverweeds - as well as the Theaceae-segregate [[Bonnetiaceae]] need to be included in this group. Their inclusions make Clusiaceae in a wide-sense polyphyletic, and Stevens's subfamilies need to be recognised at family level: Clusioideae as Clusiaceae sensu stricto; Hypericoideae as [[Hypericaceae]]; and Kielmeyeroideae as [[Calophyllaceae]].<ref>APG III (2009)</ref>
<!-- The classification of subfamily Clusioideae is not yet fully established ! -->
==Subfamily Clusioideae== :Tribe [[Clusieae]] ::''[[Chrysochlamys]]'' (''Balboa'', ''Tovomitopsis'') ::''[[Clusia]]'' (''Androstylium'', ''Cochlanthera'', ''Decaphalangium'', ''Havetia'', ''Havetiopsis'', ''Oedematopus'', ''Oxystemon'', ''Pilosperma'', ''Quapoya'', ''Renggeria'', ''Rengifa'') ::''[[Tovomita]]'' (''Marialvaea'', ''Tovomitidium'')
:Tribe [[Chrysopieae]] ::''[[Chrysopia]]''
:Tribe [[Garcinieae]] ::''[[Garcinia]]'' (''Brindonia'', ''Cambogia'', ''Clusianthemum'', ''Mangostana'', ''Oxycarpus'', ''Pentaphalangium'', ''Rheedia'', ''Septogarcinia'', ''Tripetalum'', ''Tsimatimia'', ''Verticillaria'', ''Xanthochymus'') - [[saptree]], [[mangosteen]]
:Tribe [[Moronobeeae]] ::''[[Moronobea]]''
:Tribe [[Platonieae]] ::''[[Platonia]]'' (''Aristoclesia'')
:Tribe [[Symphonieae]] ::''[[Montrouziera]]'' ::''[[Symphonia (plant)|Symphonia]]''
:Tribe ? ::''[[Allanblackia]]'' ::''[[Dystovomita]]'' ::''[[Lorostemon]]'' ::''[[Pentadesma]]'' ::''[[Thysanostemon]]''
==Subfamily Hypericoideae== This subfamily comprises 3 tribes:
:Tribe [[Cratoxyleae]] ::''[[Cratoxylum]]'' (''Cratoxylon'') ::''[[Eliea]]'' (''Eliaea'') ::''[[Thornea]]'' ::''[[Triadenum]]'' - [[marsh St. Johnswort]]
:Tribe [[Hypericeae]] ::''[[Hypericum]]'' (''Adenotrias'', ''Androsaemum'', ''Androsemum'', ''Ascyrum'', ''Lianthus'', ''Olympia'', ''Sanidophyllum'', ''Sarothra'', ''Takasagoya'', ''Triadenia'') - [[St John's Wort]] ::''[[Santomasia]]''
:Tribe [[Vismieae]] ::''[[Harungana]]'' (''Haronga'') ::''[[Psorospermum]]'' ::''[[Vismia]]''
==Subfamily Kielmeyeroideae== This subfamily comprises 2 tribes:
:Tribe [[Calophylleae]] (12 genera) ::''[[Calophyllum]]'' ::''[[Caraipa]]'' ::''[[Clusiella]]'' (''Asthotheca'', ''Astrotheca'') ::''[[Haploclathra]]'' ::''[[Kayea]]'' ::''[[Kielmeyera]]'' ::''[[Mahurea]]'' ::''[[Mammea]]'' (''Ochrocarpos'', ''Paramammea'') - [[Mammea|mammee apple]] (sometimes put in [[Garcinieae]]) ::''[[Marila]]'' ::''[[Mesua]]'' (''Vidalia'') ::''[[Neotatea]]'' ::''[[Poeciloneuron]]''
:Tribe [[Endodesmieae]] (contains 2 [[Africa]]n [[monotypic]] genera) ::''[[Endodesmia]]'' ::''[[Lebrunia (plant)|Lebrunia]]''

page.title: List of Minnesota trees by family

revision.comment: /* Broadleaf trees */ [[Rhamnus alnifolia]] is a shrub
revision.text:
{{For|a similar list organized by scientific name|List of Minnesota trees by scientific name}} This is a list of all the [[Pinophyta|coniferous]] and [[Flowering plant|broadleaf]] trees native to Minnesota by [[family (biology)|family]].
==Coniferous trees== * Cupressaceae (cypress family) ** ''[[Juniperus virginiana]]'' (eastern juniper or red cedar) ** ''[[Thuja occidentalis]]'' (eastern arborvitae or white cedar) * Pinaceae (pine family) ** ''[[Abies balsamea]]'' (balsam fir) ** ''[[Larix laricina]]'' (tamarack larch) ** ''[[Pinus banksiana]]'' (jack pine) ** ''[[Pinus strobus]]'' (eastern white pine) ** ''[[Pinus resinosa]]'' (red pine or Norway pine) ** ''[[Picea glauca]]'' (white spruce) ** ''[[Picea mariana]]'' (black spruce) ** ''[[Tsuga canadensis]]'' (eastern hemlock)
==Broadleaf trees== * Betulaceae (birch family) ** ''[[Betula alleghaniensis]]'' (yellow birch) ** ''[[Betula nigra]]'' (river birch) ** ''[[Betula papyrifera]]'' (paper birch) ** ''[[Carpinus caroliniana]]'' (American hornbeam, blue beech, ironwood) ** ''[[Ostrya virginiana]]'' (ironwood, hophornbeam) * Fabaceae (pea family) ** ''[[Gleditsia triacanthos]]'' (honey locust) ** ''[[Gymnocladus dioicus]]'' (Kentucky coffeetree) * Fagaceae (beech family) ** ''[[Quercus alba]]'' (white oak) ** ''[[Quercus bicolor]]'' (swamp white oak) ** ''[[Quercus ellipsoidalis]]'' (northern pin oak) ** ''[[Quercus macrocarpa]]'' (bur oak) ** ''[[Quercus muehlenbergii]]'' (chinkapin oak) ** ''[[Quercus prinus]]'' (chestnut oak) ** ''[[Quercus rubra]]'' (northern red oak) ** ''[[Quercus velutina]]'' (black oak) * Juglandaceae (walnut family) ** ''[[Carya cordiformis]]'' (bitternut hickory) ** ''[[Carya ovata]]'' (shagbark hickory) ** ''[[Juglans cinerea]]'' (butternut) ** ''[[Juglans nigra]]'' (black walnut) * Malvaceae (mallow family) ** ''[[Tilia americana]]'' (basswood) * Moraceae (mulberry family) ** ''[[Morus rubra]]'' (red mulberry) * Oleaceae (olive family) ** ''[[Fraxinus americana]]'' (white ash) ** ''[[Fraxinus nigra]]'' (black ash) ** ''[[Fraxinus pennsylvanica]]'' (green ash and red ash) * Rosaceae (rose family) ** ''[[Prunus pensylvanica]]'' (pin cherry) ** ''[[Prunus serotina]]'' (black cherry) ** ''[[Sorbus americana]]'' (American mountain ash) ** ''[[Sorbus decora]]'' (showy rowan) * Salicaceae (willow family) ** ''[[Populus tremuloides]]'' (quaking aspen) ** ''[[Populus grandidentata]]'' (big-tooth aspen) ** ''[[Populus balsamifera]]'' (balsam poplar) ** ''[[Populus deltoides]]'' (eastern cottonwood) ** ''[[Salix nigra]]'' (black willow) ** ''[[Salix amygdaloides]]'' (peachleaf willow) * Sapindaceae (soapberry family) ** ''[[Acer negundo]]'' (boxelder) ** ''[[Acer nigrum]]'' (black maple) ** ''[[Acer rubrum]]'' (red maple) ** ''[[Acer saccharinum]]'' (silver maple) ** ''[[Acer saccharum]]'' (sugar maple) ** ''[[Acer spicatum]]'' (mountain maple) * Ulmaceae (elm family) ** ''[[Celtis occidentalis]]'' (hackberry) ** ''[[Ulmus americana]]'' (American elm) ** ''[[Ulmus rubra]]'' (slippery elm) ** ''[[Ulmus thomasii]]'' (rock elm)
==Introduced and invasive species== [[Introduced species|Introduced]] and [[invasive species]] of trees include: * Aceraceae (Maples) ** ''[[Acer ginnala]]'' (Amur maple) ** ''[[Acer platanoides]]'' (Norway maple) * Fabaceae ** ''[[Robinia pseudoacacia]]'' (black locust) * Rhamnaceae ([[Buckthorn]]s) ** ''[[Frangula alnus]]'' (glossy buckthorn, alder buckthorn) ** ''[[Rhamnus cathartica]]'' (common buckthorn) * Hippocastanaceae (buckeye and horsechestnut) ** ''[[Aesculus glabra]]'' (Ohio buckeye) ** ''[[Aesculus hippocastanum]]'' (European horsechestnut) * Ulmaceae (Elm) ** ''[[Ulmus glabra]]'' (Wych elm)<ref>{{eFloras|1|233501327|Ulmus glabra |family=Ulmaceae |first=Susan L. |last=Sherman-Broyles}}</ref><ref>{{BONAP |genus=Ulmus |species=glabra}}</ref> ** ''[[Ulmus pumila]]'' (Siberian elm) * Pinaceae (Pine) ** ''[[Larix decidua]]'' (European larch) ** ''[[Picea abies]]'' (Norway spruce) ** ''[[Picea pungens]]'' (Colorado blue spruce)<ref>{{BONAP |genus=Pinus |species=pungens}}</ref> ** ''[[Pinus rigida]]'' (pitch pine)<ref>{{BONAP |genus=Pinus |species=rigida}}</ref> ** ''[[Pinus sylvestris]]'' (Scots pine) * Salicaceae (willow) ** ''[[Populus alba]]'' (white poplar) * Eleagnaceae (olive) ** ''[[Elaeagnus angustifolia]]'' (Russian olive)

Like other crops cocoa can be attacked by a number of pest species including [[fungal diseases]], [[insect]]s and [[rodent]]s - some of which (e.g. [[frosty pod rot]] and [[cocoa pod borer]]) have increased dramatically in geographical range and are sometimes described as "[[invasive species]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.dropdata.org/cocoa/cocoa_prob.htm|title=The World's Worst Cocoa Problems|author=|date=|website=www.dropdata.org|accessdate=24 June 2018}} ==Bacterial diseases== {| class="wikitable" style="clear:left" ! colspan=2| '''[[Bacteria]]l diseases'''
|- |[[Crown gall]] ||''[[Agrobacterium tumefaciens]]'' (artificial inoculations) |- |Stripe ||''[[Erwinia caratovora]]'' |- |} ==Fungal diseases== {| class="wikitable" style="clear" ! colspan=2| '''[[Fungal]] and [[Oomycete]] diseases'''

{{=}} ''[[Botryodiplodia theobromae]]'' |- |Leaf anthracnose ||''[[Colletotrichum]]'' spp. |- |Macrophoma pod rot ||''[[Macrophoma]]'' spp. |- |Moniliophthora pod rot ||''[[Moniliophthora roreri]]'' |- |Phytophthora pod rot || ''[[Phytophthora capsici]]''

The '''paleognaths''' ('''[[Palaeognathae]]''') are a [[clade]] of [[bird]] [[species]] of [[Gondwana|gondwanic]] distribution in [[Africa]], [[South America]], [[New Guinea]], [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]]. The group have more than 50 living [[species]] and includes the '''ostriches''', '''rheas''', '''kiwis''', '''emus''', '''cassowaries''' and '''tinamous'''. They are, with [[Neognathae]], the two main lineages of modern birds ([[Neornithes]]).{{cite book|first1=J.|last1=del Hoyo|first2=A.|last2=Elliott|first3=J.|last3=Sargatal|publisher=Lynx Edicions|title=Handbook of the Birds of the World. Volume 1: Ostrich to Ducks|year=1992|isbn=84-87334-10-5}}{{cite book |last1='''Clements''' |first1=James |authorlink= James Clements|title=The Clements Checklist of the Birds of the World |edition=6 |year=2007 |publisher= Cornell University Press|location=Ithaca, NY |isbn=978-0-8014-4501-9}}[[IOC World Bird List]] v6.3 [http://www.worldbirdnames.org/]. {{cite web | url=http://www.worldbirdnames.org/IOC_Names_File_Plus-6.3.xlsx | title=''IOC Names File Plus 6.3'' | accessdate=30 August 2016}}{{cite web|website=English Names of Birds |last=Çınar|first=Ümüt|year=November 2015|title=''01 → Pᴀʟᴇᴏɢɴᴀᴛʜᴀᴇ : Sᴛʀᴜᴛʜɪᴏɴɪfᴏʀᴍᴇs, Rʜᴇɪfᴏʀᴍᴇs, Cᴀsᴜᴀʀɪɪfᴏʀᴍᴇs, Aᴘᴛᴇʀʏɢɪfᴏʀᴍᴇs, Aᴇᴘʏᴏʀɴɪᴛʜɪfᴏʀᴍᴇs, Dɪɴᴏʀɴɪᴛʜɪfᴏʀᴍᴇs, Lɪᴛʜᴏʀɴɪᴛʜɪfᴏʀᴍᴇs, Tɪɴᴀᴍɪfᴏʀᴍᴇs & Rᴇfᴇʀᴇɴᴄᴇs'' |url=http://kmoksy.com/zobot/birds_English.html |accessdate= 30 December 2015}} Extinct species assignment follows the Mikko's Phylogeny Archive,{{cite web|website=[[Mikko's Phylogeny Archive]] |last=Haaramo|first=Mikko|year=2007|title=''Paleognathia - paleognathous modern birds'' |url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~mhaaramo/metazoa/deuterostoma/chordata/archosauria/aves/palaeognathia/paleognathia_1.html |accessdate= 30 December 2015}} Paleofile.com website{{cite web|website=[[Paleofile.com (net, info)]] |url=http://www.paleofile.com/ |title=''Taxonomic lists- Aves'' |accessdate=30 December 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160111195520/http://paleofile.com/ |archivedate=11 January 2016 |df= }} and Brodkob.{{cite journal|author=Brodkob, Pierce|year=1963| title=''Catalogue of fossil birds 1- Archaeopterygiformes through Ardeiformes'' | url=http://ufdc.ufl.edu/UF00001514/00001|journal=[[Biological sciences]], Bulletin of the Florida State Museum| volume=7|issue=4|page=180-293| accessdate=30 December 2015}} ==Summary of 2006 [[IUCN Red List]] categories==
{{IUCN_3.1 navmap/full}}
Conservation status [v2017.3, the data is current as of May 8, 2018]:{{cite web| website=''[[IUCN Red List]]'' | last=IUCN| year=2017| title=''IUCN Red List of Threatened Species''| edition=2017.3 |url=http://www.iucnredlist.org/static/categories_criteria_3_1 |accessdate= 8 May 2018}} :{{IUCN status|EX}} - extinct, :{{IUCN status|EW}} - extinct in the wild :{{IUCN status|CR}} - critically endangered :{{IUCN status|EN}} - endangered :{{IUCN status|VU}} - vulnerable :{{IUCN status|NT}} - near threatened :{{IUCN status|LC}} - least concern :{{IUCN status|DD}} - data deficient :{{IUCN page.title: List of plants known as oil palm

revision.text:
'''Oil palm''' refers to several palms that yield oil from fruit pulp and seeds, primarily
* ''[[Elaeis guineensis]]'', the African oil palm, the major [[palm oil]] crop species
but also: * ''[[Attalea maripa]]'', the maripa palm * ''[[Coconut|Cocos nucifera]]'', the coconut palm, which yields [[coconut oil]] from its seeds * ''[[Elaeis oleifera]]'', the American oil palm * The genus ''[[Elaeis]]'', with just two species, ''E. guineensis'' and ''E. oleifera'', referred to as the oil-palm genus
==See also== * [[Wax palm]]
{{Palm oil}} {{Plant common name}}
[[Category:Oil palm|Σ]] [[Category:Forestry-related lists|Oil palm]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox park | name = Marineland of Antibes | photo = Vue globale bassins Marineland.jpg | photo_caption = Global view of the [[killer whale]]s tanks | type = [[Amusement park]], [[dolphinarium]], [[public aquarium]], marine [[zoo]] | location = [[Antibes]], [[France]] | coords = | area = 26 ha | created = 1970 | operator = [[Parques Reunidos]] | status = Closed until march 21th due to storm damage. }}
The '''Marineland of Antibes''' is a [[Amusement park|theme park]] founded in 1970 by [[Roland de la Poype|Roland de La Poype]] in [[Antibes]] ([[Alpes-Maritimes]]), in the [[French Riviera]]. On 26 hectares it includes a marine [[zoological park]] with [[dolphinarium]], a [[water park]] (''Aquasplash''), a children's play park (''Kid's Island''), a mini golf (''Aventure Golf'') and a three-star hotel (''Marineland Resort''). It is the property of the Spanish multinational company [[Parques Reunidos]], whose majority shareholder is the British investment fund Arle Capital Partners. The actual director is Arnaud Palu.
It is one of the four French dolphinariums and one of the two European dolphinariums presenting [[Killer whale|orcas]]. With 1.2 million visitors in 2014, it's the most visited site of the [[Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur|Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region]]. The zoological park is one of the most visited in France.
Since the 2010s, it is more and more criticised by the opponents to [[cetacea]]n captivity, which claims that dolphinariums can't assure captivity conditions that fits to the proper needs of those [[species]], leading to a prematurate mortality of individuals.
== History == On July 25, 2006, the park was sold to the Spanish amusement park group [[Parques Reunidos]] for about 75 million Euros<ref>[http://www.tourmag.com/Antibes-Marineland-ouvre-son-premier-hotel_a73658.html Tourmag.com]</ref>
==Animal exhibits== {{Advert|date=October 2015}} [[File:Funala55.JPG|thumb|right|The ''Shark Tunnel'']] [[File:Zalotttt.JPG|thumb|right|[[California sea lion]] of the park]] [[File:Orso Bianco Antibes.JPG|thumb|right|The area of the [[polar bear]]s]]
;Killer whale show The largest killer whale pool complex in the world performing in {{Convert|11000000|gal|m3}} of water, with a panoramic glass wall {{Convert|64|m}} long. Marineland holds four [[orcas]]: Inouk, [[Wikie (killer whale)|Wikie]], Moana and Keijo.
;Dolphin show Marineland is currently housing (Apr 2017) a total of 13 [[bottlenose dolphins]]. The name of the dolphins are: Ecume (F), Lotty (F), Sharky (F), Malou (F), Éclair (M), Alize (M), Rocky (M), Dam (M), Neo (M), Mila-Tami (F), Nala (F), Ania (F), and Joseph (M).
;Les Coulisses de l'apprentissage (sea lion show) A live demonstration of the learning techniques used with all the mammals in the park, in which the [[pinniped|seal]] and [[sea lion]] trainers disclose some of the "ropes" for preparing the show, the better to understand the basis of the relationship between humans and animals.
;The shark tunnel In a {{Convert|30|m|sing=on}} tunnel through an aquarium containing nearly {{Convert|2000000|l|gal}} of water, visitors are surrounded by [[shark]]s and [[manta rays]].
;Polar bears Marineland is one of few places in Europe where one can see [[polar bear]]s. As of 2015, there are 3 of them: one male (Rasputin), one female (Flocke), and their cub (Hope).
;Life under the sea (The tropical aquarium gallery and The touch pool) The tropical aquarium gallery shows the world of coral reefs, and the touch pool is a chance to touch skates and rays - fish that seem to "fly" in the water.
;[[Pinnipeds]] Beaches featuring California sea lions, South American sea lions, black seals and grey seals.
;Aquatic birds Beaches featuring [[penguins]], [[pelicans]] and [[flamingos]].
;Meeting with dolphins Each session lasts approximately 1 hour, to discover the biology and ecology of [[dolphins]], before approaching the [[dolphins]] for 20 minutes under close supervision by trainers on a sunken deck.
==Gallery== <center> <gallery perrow="6"> File:Dolphin_France.JPG|[[Dolphin]] File:Ours_polaire_antibes.jpg|[[Polar bear]] File:Apperò.JPG|[[Nurse shark]] File:Humboldt penguins Marineland Antibes 1.jpg|[[Humboldt penguin]]s File:Carettaaaaaa.JPG|[[Loggerhead sea turtle]] File:Sea Lion FR.JPG|[[Steller sea lion]] File:Pinguini Z.JPG|Antarctica Zone with [[king penguin]]s, [[southern rockhopper penguin]]s, [[gentoo penguin]]s and [[macaroni penguin]]s File:Dauphins_antibes.jpg|[[Dolphin]] show </gallery> </center>
==References== {{Commons category|Marineland d'Antibes}} {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.marineland.fr/ MarineLand website] *[http://www.orcahome.de/antibes.htm Orcahome]

{{Canadianpetroleumhistory}} [[File:Canada Proved Oil Reserves.png|thumb|Canada proved oil reserves: conventional crude oil in red (data from OPEC) and total proved reserves including from oil sands in black (data from US Energy Information Administration)]] [[File:Canada Conventional Oil Proved Reserves.png|thumb|Conventional crude oil reserves in Canada (excludes condensate, natural gas liquids, and petroleum from oil sands).]]
'''Oil reserves in [[Canada]]''' were estimated at {{convert|172|Goilbbl|e9m3|sigfig=2}} as of the start of 2015 . This figure includes the [[oil sands]] reserves that are estimated by government regulators to be economically producible at current prices using current technology.<ref>{{cite web | last = EIA | title = International Energy Statistics | publisher = Energy Information Administration of the U.S. Department of Energy |year=2015 | url = http://www.eia.doe.gov/cfapps/ipdbproject/IEDIndex3.cfm?tid=5&pid=57&aid=6 | accessdate = 2015-03-10 }} </ref> According to this figure, Canada's reserves are third only to [[Oil reserves in Venezuela|Venezuela]] and [[Oil reserves in Saudi Arabia|Saudi Arabia]]. Over 95% of these reserves are in the [[oil sands]] deposits in the province of [[Alberta]].<ref name="EIACAN">{{cite web | author = EIA | title = Country Analysis Brief: Canada | publisher = U.S. Energy Information Administration |year=2007 | url = http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/Canada/Oil.html | accessdate = 2007-10-07 }}</ref> Alberta contains nearly all of Canada's oil sands and much of its conventional oil reserves. The balance is concentrated in several other provinces and territories. [[Saskatchewan]] and offshore areas of [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]] in particular have substantial oil production and reserves.<ref> {{Cite journal | author = USask | title = Canadian frontier petroleum | publisher = University of Saskatchewan |year=2006 | url = https://www.usask.ca/geology/classes/geol463/463frontier.doc | format = DOC | accessdate = 2006-12-04 }} </ref> Alberta has 39% of Canada's remaining conventional oil reserves, offshore Newfoundland 28% and Saskatchewan 27%, but if oil sands are included, Alberta's share is over 98%.<ref name="NEB_CEO">{{cite web | author = NEB | title = Canadian Energy Overview 2007 | publisher = National Energy Board of Canada | date = May 2008 | url = http://www.neb.gc.ca/clf-nsi/rnrgynfmtn/nrgyrprt/nrgyvrvw/cndnnrgyvrvw2007/cndnnrgyvrvw2007-eng.html#s4_4 | accessdate = 2008-07-30}} </ref>
==Status== [[File:Canadian oil production 1950 to 2030.svg|lang=en|thumb|left|Canadian conventional oil production peaked in 1973, but oil sands production is forecast to increase to at least 2020]]
Canada has a highly sophisticated energy industry and is both an importer and exporter of oil and refined products. In 2006, in addition to producing {{convert|1.2|Goilbbl|e6m3}}, Canada imported {{convert|440|Moilbbl|e6m3}}, consumed {{convert|800|Moilbbl|e6m3}} itself, and exported {{convert|840|Moilbbl|e6m3}} to the U.S.<ref name="EIACAN" /> The excess of exports over imports was {{convert|400|Moilbbl|e6m3}}. Over 99% of Canadian oil exports are sent to the United States, and Canada is the United States' largest supplier of oil.<ref>{{cite web | last = EIA | title = Crude Oil and Total Petroleum Imports Top 15 Countries October 2007 Import Highlights: Released on December 28, 2007 | publisher = Energy Information Administration of the U.S. Department of Energy |date=2007-12-28 | url = http://www.eia.doe.gov/pub/oil_gas/petroleum/data_publications/company_level_imports/current/import.html | accessdate = 2007-10-07 }} </ref>
The decision of accounting {{convert|174|Goilbbl|e9m3|sigfig=2}} of the Alberta oil sands deposits as proven reserves was made by the [[Energy Resources Conservation Board]] (ERCB), now known as the [[Alberta Energy and Utilities Board]] (AEUB).<ref name="ST98">{{Cite journal | author = ERCB | title = ST98: Alberta's Energy Reserves 2007 and Supply/Demand Outlook 2008-2017 | publisher = Alberta Energy Resources Conservation Board | year = 2008 | url = http://www.ercb.ca/portal/server.pt/gateway/PTARGS_0_0_308_0_0_43/http%3B/ercbContent/publishedcontent/publish/ercb_home/publications_catalogue/publications_available/serial_publications/st98.aspx | accessdate = 2008-07-29 }}</ref> Although now widely accepted, this addition was controversial at the time because oil sands contain an extremely heavy form of crude oil known as [[bitumen]] which will not flow toward a well under reservoir conditions. Instead, it must be mined, heated, or diluted with solvents to allow it to be produced, and must be upgraded to lighter oil to be usable by refineries.<ref name="ST98" /> Historically known as bituminous sands or sometimes as "tar sands", the deposits were exposed as major rivers cut through the oil-bearing formations to reveal the bitumen in the river banks. In recent years technological breakthroughs have overcome the economical and technical difficulties of producing the oil sands, and by 2007 64% of Alberta's petroleum production of {{convert|1.86|Moilbbl/d|m3/d}} was from oil sands rather than conventional oil fields. The ERCB estimates that by 2017 oil sands production will make up 88% of Alberta's predicted oil production of {{convert|3.4|Moilbbl/d|m3/d}}.<ref name="ST98" />
[[Image:WTI Crude Oil Price 1998-2007.png|thumb|right|The fivefold increase in oil prices from 1998 to 2007 made Canadian oil sands production profitable.]]
Analysts estimate that a price of $30 to $40 per barrel is required to make new oil sands production profitable.<ref name="EIACAN" /> In recent years prices have greatly exceeded those levels and the Alberta government expects $116 billion worth of new oil sands projects to be undertaken between 2008 and 2017.<ref name="ST98" /> However the biggest constraint on oil sands development is a serious labor and housing shortage in Alberta as a whole and the oil sands centre of [[Fort McMurray]] in particular. According to [[Statistics Canada]], by September, 2006 unemployment rates in Alberta had fallen to record low levels<ref>{{cite web |last=Cross |first=Philip |author2=Geoff Bowlby |title=The Alberta economic juggernaut |work=Canadian Economic Observer |publisher=Statistics Canada |date=September 2006 |url=http://www.statcan.ca/english/ads/11-010-XPB/pdf/sep06.pdf |format=PDF |doi= |accessdate=2006-12-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090326023337/http://www.statcan.gc.ca/ads-annonces/11-010-x/pdf/6000725-eng.pdf |archivedate=March 26, 2009 |df= }} </ref> and per-capita incomes had risen to double the Canadian average. Another hurdle has been Canada's capacity to rapidly increase its export pipelines. The [[National Energy Board]] indicated that exporters faced pipeline [[rationing|apportionment]] in 2007.<ref> {{cite web | last = NEB | title = Capacity constraints coming | work = 2007 Canadian Hydrocarbon Transportation System Assessment | publisher = National Energy Board of Canada |date=July 2007 | url = http://www.neb.gc.ca/clf-nsi/rthnb/nwsrls/2007/nwsrls23-eng.html | accessdate = 2007-08-14 }}</ref> However, surging crude oil prices sparked a jump in applications for oil pipelines in 2007, and new pipelines were planned to carry Canadian oil as far south as U.S. refineries on the Gulf of Mexico.<ref> {{cite web | last = NEB | title = Surging crude oil prices sparked a jump in applications for oil pipelines in 2007 | publisher = National Energy Board of Canada | date = 6 May 2008 | url = http://www.neb.gc.ca/clf-nsi/rthnb/nwsrls/2008/nwsrls19-eng.html | accessdate = 2008-07-30 }}</ref>
Up until 2010 Canada was the only major oil producer in the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development ([[OECD]]) to have an increase in oil production in recent years. Production in the other major OECD producers (the United States, United Kingdom, Norway and Mexico) at that time have been declining, as was conventional oil production in Canada. Total crude oil production in Canada was projected to increase by an average of 8.6 percent per year from 2008 to 2011 as a result of new non-conventional oil projects.<ref> {{cite web | last = Clavet | first = Frederic | title = Canada's Oil Extraction Industry: Industrial Outlook, Winter 2007 | publisher = The Conference Board of Canada |date=February 2007 | url = http://www.conferenceboard.ca/documents.asp?rnext=1916 | accessdate = 2007-04-01}} </ref>
==See also== * [[Athabasca Oil Sands]] * [[History of the petroleum industry in Canada (oil sands and heavy oil)]]
== External links == * [http://www.oilandgasinfrastructure.com/home/oilandgasnorthamerica/canada Map of Canadian Oil and gas infrastructure]
==References== {{Reflist}}
