{{Infobox ancient site |name = Tel Sheva |native_name = תל באר שבע |alternate_name = |image = Tel Be'er Sheva Overview 2007041.JPG |alt = |caption = Overview |map_type = Israel |map_size = 150 |map_alt = |coordinates = {{coord|31|14|41|N|34|50|27|E|display=inline,title}} |location = Near [[Beersheba]], Israel |region = |type = Settlement |part_of = |length = |width = |area = |height = |builder = |material = |built = |abandoned = |epochs = |cultures = |dependency_of = |occupants = |event = |excavations = |archaeologists = |condition = |ownership = |management = |public_access = |website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> |notes = |designation1 = WHS |designation1_offname = Biblical Tells – [[Megiddo (place)|Megiddo]], [[Hazor (archaeological site)|Hazor]], Beer Sheba |designation1_date = 2005 <small>(29th [[World Heritage Committee|session]])</small> |designation1_number = [http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1108 1108] |designation1_criteria = ii, iii, iv, vi |designation1_type = Cultural |designation1_free1name = State Party |designation1_free1value= [[Israel]] |designation1_free2name = Region |designation1_free2value= [[List of World Heritage Sites in Asia and Australasia|Asia-Pacific]] }}
'''Tel Be'er Sheva''' (Hebrew) or '''Tell es-Seba''' (Arabic)<ref name="Dauphin">{{cite book | author = Claudine Dauphin | title = La Palestine byzantine, Peuplement et Populations, Vol. III : Catalogue | series = BAR International Series 726 | year = 1998 | publisher = Archeopress | location = Oxford | page = 960 }}</ref> is an [[archeological]] site in southern [[Israel]] believed to be the remains of the biblical town of [[Beersheba]].<ref name=NegevGibson>{{cite book |work=Archaeological Encyclopedia of the Holy Land |title=Beer Sheba |author=Avraham Negev and Shimon Gibson |year=2001 |location=New York and London |publisher=Continuum |page=73 |isbn=0-8264-1316-1 }}</ref> It lies east of the modern city of Beersheba and west of the new Bedouin town of [[Tel Sheva]]/Tell as-Sabi. Tel Sheva has been preserved and made accessible to visitors in the '''Tel Be'er Sheva National Park''' ({{lang-he|תל באר שבע}}).<ref name=brochure>{{cite web |url=http://www.parks.org.il/ParksAndReserves/telBeerSheva/Documents/tel-beer-sheva-en.pdf |title=Tel Beer Sheva National Park |author=Professor Ze’ev Herzog |publisher=Israel Nature and Parks Authority |date= |access-date=May 1, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140902163212/http://www.parks.org.il/ParksAndReserves/telBeerSheva/Documents/tel-beer-sheva-en.pdf |archivedate=September 2, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
==Etymology== The name is derived from the [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] ''be'er'', meaning a well, and ''sheva'', meaning "seven".
==History ==
{{Empty section|date=May 2015}}
==In the Hebrew Bible== Beer-sheba is mentioned 33 times in the biblical text. It is often used when describing a border, such as “from Dan to Beer-sheba” (Judges 20:1; 1 Sam. 3:20; 2 Sam. 3:10, 17:11, 24:2, 24:15; 1 Kings 4:25; 2 Kings 23:8), but it is also a significant center in the patriarchal narratives. Abraham dwelt at Beer-sheba (Genesis 22:19), Abraham and Abimelech entered a covenant at Beer-sheba (Genesis 21:32), and Abraham planted a tamarisk tree at Beer-sheba (Genesis 21:33). The Lord spoke to both Isaac and Jacob, Abraham’s son and grandson respectively, at Beer-sheba (Genesis 26:23; Genesis 46:1). Beer-sheba is also the site of two significant wells: Abraham’s well at Beer-sheba was seized by Abimelech’s men (Genesis 21:25), and Isaac’s servants dug a well at Beer-sheba also (Genesis 26:25). Additionally, archaeological evidence of the dismantling of the altar at Tel Beer-sheba strongly supports a correlation with the biblical account of the cultic reform carried out by King Hezekiah (2 Kings 18:22).<ref>"Horned Altar for Animal Sacrifice Unearthed at Beer-Sheva." ''The Biblical Archaeology Review'' 1, no. 1 (1975): 1.</ref>
==Excavation== Tel Beer-sheba, the site of the ancient city, is located on a hill overlooking the Wadi Beer-sheba about two and a half miles east of the modern city of [[Beersheba]]. The site was excavated from 1969 to 1976 by the Tel Aviv University Institute of Archaeology, directed by Prof. [[Yohanan Aharoni]], except for the last season which was led by Prof. [[Ze'ev Herzog]]. Most of the dig was devoted to uncovering the great, fortified, Israelite city traditionally dating to the United Monarchy of [[King David]] (his reign being dated from 1000 B.C.E.) and, later, to the kingdom of [[Kingdom of Judah|Judah]] (980–701 B.C.E.). During the last three seasons of excavation (1974–1976), an effort was made to go below Beer-sheba of Iron Age II to find earlier occupation. A considerable part of the site was dug down to bedrock in order to find the earliest settlements at Beer-sheba. This effort revealed four earlier occupational strata (Strata VI through IX).<ref>Herzog, Ze’ev. "Beer-Sheba of the Patriarchs." ''Biblical Archaeology Review'' 6, no. 6 (1980):12-28. Accessed October 14, 2015. http://www.basarchive.org.ezp-prod1.hul.harvard.edu/bswbBrowse.asp?PubID=BSBA&Volume=6&Issue=6&ArticleID=3&UserID=2216</ref> Excavations were renewed by Prof Herzog between 1993 and 1995 in order to complete the uncovering of the town's water system.<ref name=parks/>
==Iron Age I== [[File:Mountseirsinaiwe00hull Page 173.png|thumb|right|[[Abrahams Well]] 1855.]] The earliest occupation at Beer-sheba during Iron Age I (Stratum IX) was represented only by seven large pits about 22 to 25 feet in diameter. Archaeologists believe that the entire settlement of this stratum covered about 2,990 sq. yards, approximately the area of half of a football field. It likely contained about 20 dwelling pits and 10 granaries and would have housed from 100 to 140 people. Stratum IX was abandoned then reused, new structures being added to the old. In Stratum VIII, which dates to the 11th century B.C.E., archaeologists found houses for the first time. Like Stratum IX, Stratum VIII was abandoned rather than destroyed. The pottery suggests that the same people who lived in Stratum VIII built Stratum VII at the end of the 11th century B.C.E., which comprised five domestic units in a possibly enclosed settlement.<ref name="ReferenceA">Herzog, “Beer-Sheba of the Patriarchs.”</ref>
==Iron Age II==
The settlement of Beer-sheba was probably first fortified during the Iron IIA. Some archaeologists believe that Beer-sheba, which was on the southern border of the fledgling Israelite kingdom, was fortified by King Saul at the end of the 11th century B.C.E. during wars against the [[Amalekites]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/> However, on the basis of interregional comparisons and recent radiocarbon evidence, this settlement phase probably belongs in the late – 10th or 9th century B.C.E.<ref>Boaretto, E. et al. Dating the Iron Age I/II Transition in Israel: first intercomparison results. Radiocarbon 47(1), 2005; Finkelstein, I., and Piasetzky, E. Radiocarbon-dated Destruction Layers: A skeleton for Iron Age chronology in the Levant. Oxford Journal of Archaeology 28(3), 2009; Mazar, A. The Iron Age Chronology Debate; Is the gap narrowing? Another viewpoint. Near Eastern Archaeology 74(1): 105-111, 2011</ref> The best preserved layout of the Iron II city may be reconstructed from Stratum II, which dates to the late 8th century B.C.E. during the Iron IIB. At this time, the city was destroyed in a conflagration, possibly during the campaign of Sennacherib in 701 B.C.E. Reconstructed plans of the city suggest that Beer-sheba was planned as a coherent entity with areas for administrative structures and for dwellings incorporated into a single system. Fortifications included a [[casemate wall]] and a four-room city gate. Drains running under some of the streets conducted rain-water out of the city and a well-preserved water system of cisterns provided the inhabitants with water. The incorporation of the houses into the casemate wall suggests that its occupants were directly responsible for the city’s defense and reflects the military and administrative function of the entire city. Archaeologists estimate around 350 people lived in the city of Beer-sheba during this period.<ref>Herzog, Ze'ev. Archaeology of the City: Urban Planning in Ancient Israel and Its Social Implications. Tel Aviv: Emery and Claire Yass Archaeology Press, 1997: 246.</ref>
==National park; UNESCO recognition== The site was restored by the [[Israel Nature and Parks Authority]] in 1990. In 2003, its water system was opened to the public as well. The excavated town is now open for visitors under the name Tel Be'er Sheva National Park.<ref name=parks/>
In 2007, Tel Sheva was recognized as a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]]. Of more than 200 tels in Israel, Beersheba was cited as one of the most representative, containing substantial remains of a city with biblical connections.<ref name="highbeam">{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-136038939.html |title=Israel celebrates 8 new UNESCO World Heritage Sites. Biblical tels constitute 'testimony of universal value,' while Nabataean towns illustrate ancient trade routes - Jerusalem Post | HighBeam Research |publisher=highbeam.com|accessdate=March 29, 2016}}</ref>
===Horned altar=== [[Image:Tel Be'er Sheva Altar 2007041.JPG|thumb|Replica of horned altar (the original is in the [[Israel Museum]])]]
One of the most significant discoveries at Tel Beer-sheba is that of a horned animal altar, the first ever unearthed in Israel. Altars with horns at each of their four corners are mentioned frequently in the Bible (Lev. 4:7, 18, 25; Ex. 29:12, 30:2; 38:2; 1 Kings 1:50; 2:28). The altar was not found assembled in situ, but was discovered in secondary use—the stones of the altar had later been incorporated into a wall. There was an unresolved debate about the dating of the altar between Professor Aharoni and Professor Yigael Yadin of Hebrew University that remains undecided. Professor Aharoni believed that the Beer-sheba altar was one of the altars which was dismantled as part of Hezekiah’s religious reforms. Its stones were then reused in an 8th-century wall, and the wall itself was destroyed at the end of the 8th century, probably during Sennacherib’s Judean campaign of 701 B.C. However, Professor Yadin of Hebrew University dates this wall more than 100 years later than Professor Aharoni. According to Professor Yadin, the wall was probably destroyed about the time the Babylonians captured and destroyed Jerusalem (587 B.C.).<ref>”Horned Altar for Animal Sacrifice Unearthed at Beer-Sheva." ''The Biblical Archaeology Review'' 1, no. 1 (1975): 1.</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox book | name = The Birds of America | title_orig = The Birds of America; from original drawings by John James Audubon | translator = | image = Audubon Birds of America.jpg | caption = The cover shows a Louisiana heron,
[[Tricolored heron|''Egretta tricolor'']] (now called tricolored heron) | author = [[John James Audubon]] | illustrator = John James Audubon | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = | series = | subject = Birds – North America; Birds – pictorial works | genre = | publisher = | pub_date = 1827–1838 | media_type = | pages = 435 | isbn = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = [[Library of Congress Classification:Class Q -- Science#QL Zoology|QL674]] .A9 1827 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Birds of America''''' is a book by [[natural history|naturalist]] and painter [[John James Audubon]], containing illustrations of a wide variety of [[List of birds of the United States|birds of the United States]]. It was first published as a series in sections between 1827 and 1838, in [[Edinburgh]] and London. Not all of the specimens collected in the work were collected by Audubon himself, some were sent to him by [[John Kirk Townsend]] who had collected them on [[Nathaniel Jarvis Wyeth]]'s 1834 expedition with [[Thomas Nuttall]]. Mearns, B. & R. ''John Kirk Townsend: Collector of Audubon’s Western Birds and Mammals'' (2007). 'Narrative of a Journey Across the Rocky Mountains to the Columbia River' by John Kirk Townsend The work consists of 435 hand-coloured, life-size [[Printmaking|prints]], made from [[engraving|engraved]] plates, measuring around {{convert|39|by|26|in|cm}}. It includes images of six now-[[Extinction|extinc]]t birds: [[Carolina parakeet]], [[passenger pigeon]], [[Labrador duck]], [[great auk]], [[Eskimo curlew]], and [[Heath hen|pinnated grouse]].{{cite web|url=http://web4.audubon.org/bird/boa/ExtinctBirds.html|title=Birds Extincted since Audubon's time|first=National Audubon|last=Society|website=web4.audubon.org}} Art historians describe the quality of Audubon's work as being of high and printed with "artistic finesse." The plant-life backgrounds of some 50 of the bird studies were painted by Audubon's assistant [[Joseph Mason (artist)|Joseph Mason]] but he is not credited for his work in the book.Burt, DeVere. [http://www.ruthven.com/ruthven/CJR-SpringGrove/go "The Joseph Mason Project, Historic Spring Grove Cemetery and Arboretum"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222103914/http://www.ruthven.com/ruthven/CJR-SpringGrove/go |date=22 December 2015 }}. Ruthven.com website. Accessed 17 December 2015. He shot many specimen birds as well as transporting and maintaining supplies for Audubon.{{Cite news|url=http://historydetectives.nyhistory.org/2013/03/blast-from-the-past-everyone-needs-a-good-assistant/|title=Blast From the Past: Everyone Needs a Good Assistant|date=8 March 2013|work=History Detectives|access-date=27 November 2017|language=en-US}} Audubon also authored the companion book ''Ornithological Biographies''.{{Cite web|url=http://digital2.library.pitt.edu/collection/audubons-birds-america?f%5B0%5D=mods_typeOfResource_ms:%22text%22|title=Audubon's Birds of America|website=digital2.library.pitt.edu|access-date=27 November 2017}} ==Early publication history== [[File:1 Wild Turkey.jpg|thumbnail|left|Plate 1 by [[John James Audubon]] depicting a wild turkey, ([[Wild turkey|''Meleagris gallopavo'']]).]] About 1820, around the age of 35, Audubon declared his intention to paint every bird in North America.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/12/26/arts/antiques-central-park-s-winged-tenants-by-audubon.html|title=Central Park's Winged Tenants, By Audubon|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=26 December 2003}} In his bird art, he mainly forsook oil paint, the medium of serious artists of the day, in favour of [[watercolours]] and pastel crayons (and occasionally pencil, charcoal, chalk, [[gouache]], and pen and ink). As early as 1807, he developed a method of using wires and threads to hold dead birds in lifelike poses while he drew them. [[File:AudubonCarolinaParakeet2.jpg|thumbnail|upright|Audubon Carolina parakeet ([[Carolina Parakeet|''Conuropsis carolinensis'']])
now extinct]] In 1823, Audubon went to [[Philadelphia]] and New York, looking for financial support using [[Subscription business model|subscription]]s to enable him to publish his artwork. He sold the copper engraving plates through on a subscription basis in North America and Europe. Those subscribed obtained five plates at a time. Each subscriber received prints of three smaller birds, a larger bird and a mid-sized bird. The prints were produced from 1827 to 1838 that cost each subscriber around $1,000.This is equivalent to $24,600 in 2015{{Cite web|url=http://www.in2013dollars.com/1838-dollars-in-2015|title=1838 dollars in 2015 {{!}} Inflation Calculator|website=www.in2013dollars.com|language=en|access-date=27 November 2017}} It is thought that no more than 120 complete sets exist today. Each set consists of 435 individual plates that are based upon the original paintings. Each plate was engraved, printed, and hand colored by Robert Havell of London. While William Lizars, of Edinburgh, engraved the first ten plates, Havell actually finished some of those. Audubon often found support lacking. As a result, in 1826, he set sail for the United Kingdom with 250 of his original illustrations, looking for the financial support of subscribers and the technical abilities of [[Engraving|engraver]]s and printers.{{cite web|url=http://www.nls.uk/exhibitions/audubon/influence#lizars|title=Audubon and men of influence|publisher=}} After exhibiting his drawings in [[Liverpool]] and [[Manchester]], he journeyed to Edinburgh, where he met the accomplished engraver [[William H. Lizars]]. Lizars engraved up to ten of the first plates but was unable to continue the project when his colourists went on strike.{{cite web|url=http://www.liv.ac.uk/artgall/audubon/birds_of_america.htm|title=Victoria Gallery & Museum|publisher=University of Liverpool|work=liv.ac.uk}} In 1827, Audubon engaged the noted London animal engraver [[Havell family|Robert Havell Jr.]], and his father, [[Havell family|Robert Havell Sr]]. Havell Jr. oversaw the project through to its completion in 1838. [[File:Zenaida macrouraAWP17AA.jpg|thumb|upright|frameless|Carolina pigeon,
[[Mourning dove|''Zenaida macroura'']] (now called mourning dove).]] [[File:Aphelocoma coerulescens & Diospyros virginiana (Audibon).png|thumbnail|upright|''Aphelocoma coerulescens'' (Florida jay)]] The original edition of ''The Birds of America'' (sometimes called the Havell Edition{{cite web|url=http://www.minniesland.com/study_Havell_Edition.html|title=Original Audubon Prints - Antique Natural History Prints - Books - Havell - Bien - Imperial Folio - Bird and Animal Prints|work=minniesland.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100619135214/http://www.minniesland.com/study_Havell_Edition.html|archivedate=19 June 2010|df=dmy-all}} after its printer, and sometimes called the [[Book size|"Double Elephant Folio"]], because of its size) was printed on handmade paper 39.5 inches tall by 28.5 inches wide. The principal printing technique was [[intaglio printing|copperplate]] etching, but engraving and [[aquatint]] were also used. Colorists applied each color in assembly-line fashion (over fifty were hired for the work).Rhodes, 2004, pp. 273, 389. Audubon funded the costly printing project through a pay-as-you-go subscription. From 1826 to 1829, he travelled around the UK and to Paris, lecturing on ornithology and frontier American life in an effort to entice wealthy patrons to subscribe to the series of prints. Subscribers included the French king [[Charles X]], the British queen [[Adelaide of Saxe-Meiningen]], [[George Spencer, 2nd Earl Spencer|Lord Spencer]], and, later, the Americans [[Daniel Webster]] and [[Henry Clay]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/03/03/books/antiques-rarae-aves-audubon-at-auction.html|title=Rarae Aves: Audubon At Auction|newspaper=The New York Times|date=3 March 2000}} Prints were issued in sets of five every month or two in tin cases{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/25/arts/antiques-vibrant-birds-of-america-via-germany.html|title=Vibrant Birds Of America, Via Germany|newspaper=The New York Times|date=25 June 2004}} and each set usually included one very large bird, one medium-sized bird, and three small birds. The plates were published unbound and without any text to avoid having to furnish free copies to the public libraries in England. It is estimated that not more than 200 complete sets were ever compiled. An accompanying text, issued separately, was written by Audubon and the Scottish naturalist and ornithologist [[William MacGillivray]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nhm.ac.uk/nature-online/science-of-natural-history/biographies/william-macgillivray/|title=William MacGillivray|work=nhm.ac.uk}} and published in five volumes in [[Edinburgh]] between 1831 and 1839, under the title ''Ornithological Biography, or, An account of the habits of the birds of the United States of America''. The additional cost of the five volumes of text brought the total cost of plates and text to about $1000. After the folio edition was completed, Audubon decided to produce a more affordable edition and employed a lithographer from Philadelphia named J. T. Bowen. Bowen and his team created a smaller [[Octavo#Size|Royal Octavo]] edition, which was issued to subscribers in seven volumes and completed in 1844 after selling 1,199 sets.{{citation needed|date=December 2010}} Five more octavo editions were completed through 1877. The octavo edition used the text of the Ornithological biography but increased the number of plates to 500, separating some birds which had originally appeared together. Some new drawings were included, mostly by John Woodhouse though Audubon and members of Bowen's team also contributed.{{cite web |url=http://www.audubonhouse.org/audubon/octavo/bowen.cfm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100703042004/http://www.audubonhouse.org/audubon/octavo/bowen.cfm |archivedate=3 July 2010 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.abirdshome.com/Audubon/VolI/00000.html|title=The Registry Of Nature Habitats - Audubon Birds of America - Publisher's Preface|work=abirdshome.com}} The Bien Edition (after [[chromolithography]] pioneer Julius Bien), was a full-sized reissue published in 1858 by Roe Lockwood in New York under the supervision of Audubon's youngest son, John Woodhouse Audubon.{{cite web|last=Flynn|first=Ron|title=The Bien Edition / The Project, Quality, Errors and Market Value|url=http://www.auduboninfo.net/articles/BIEN%20ESSAY.htm|accessdate=30 September 2012}} Due in part to the Civil War, the edition was never finished; only 15 parts of the 44 part series were completed. This edition consisted of 105 plates and included none of the original text.{{cite web|url=http://www.audubongalleries.com/guide/guide.php |title=Audubon Galleries Original Audubon Books and Prints |publisher=Audubongalleries.com |date= |accessdate=10 December 2010}} Fewer than 100 subscriptions were sold, making this edition rarer than other early editions.{{cite web|author=Ron Flynn |url=http://www.auduboninfo.net/articles/audubon_story.htm |title=About Audubon and His Octavo Edition Prints |publisher=Auduboninfo.net |date= |accessdate=10 December 2010}} Audubon's practice of obtaining his subjects has been described as:“Audubon used what we like to call today as the barrel-of-the-shotgun method...After he killed the birds, he would use a complex system of wires and strings to position the birds. Previous artists would draw the birds in a stiff position, but Audubon was different. He drew the birds in dynamic ways, by positioning them how he would observe them in the field.” ==Public exhibitions== [[File:3 Prothonotary Warbler restored.jpg|thumb|upright|Prothonotary warbler ([[Prothonotary warbler|''Protonotaria citrea'']]) in plate 3]] A full 8-volume, double-elephant folio version is on public display in the Audubon Room at the Harlan Hatcher Graduate Library at the [[University of Michigan, Ann Arbor]]. This, the first book purchased by the University, was bought in 1839 for $970 (equivalent to ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|UK|970|1839|r=-4}}}} in {{Inflation-year|UK}}), at the time an amazing sum. The entire volume of 435 plates is also available for viewing online at the University of Michigan's website.{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.umich.edu/audubon-room/pictureit-rare-book-reader|title=PictureIt Rare Book Reader|work=umich.edu}} Since 1992, the [[Louisiana State University]] Libraries have hosted "Audubon Day," a semi-annual public showing of all four volumes of LSU's copy of the ''Birds of America.'' The set formerly belonged to one of the original subscribers, the [[Hugh Percy, 3rd Duke of Northumberland|Duke of Northumberland]], and was purchased with a grant from the Crown Zellerbach Corporation in 1964. In recent years, the event has drawn more than 200 visitors. It was profiled in a 2011 ''[[Wall Street Journal]] ''article titled "The Joys of Slow Looking."{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703421204576327750299277440|title=Birds of America by John James Audubon at Hill Memorial Library at Louisiana State University-The Joys of Slow Looking|work=Wall Street Journal|author=Willard Spiegelman|date=19 May 2011}} In 2003, the [[University of Pittsburgh]], which owns a complete collection of ''Birds of America'' that had been recently restored and preserved by the Etherington Conservation Center, mounted a major exhibition of 62 selected plates and other materials in its [[Frick Fine Arts Building#University Art Gallery|University Art Gallery]]. Following this, the university constructed an exhibit case on the ground floor of the school's [[Hillman Library]] to continuously display a rotating selection of plates to the public. Single plates have been exhibited for two weeks at a time in plate number order.{{cite web | url=http://digital.library.pitt.edu/a/audubon/about.html | title=Audubon at Pitt | publisher=University Library System, University of Pittsburgh | year=2008 | accessdate=22 August 2011}} In 2007, the university undertook a project to digitize every plate from ''Birds of America'', as well as Audubon's ''Ornithological Biography'', and, for the first time, presented the complete set for public viewing through one site on the internet.{{cite web|url=http://digital.library.pitt.edu/a/audubon/|title=Audubon's Birds of America|work=pitt.edu}}{{cite news | url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/08064/862193-42.stm | title=Audubon's 'Birds' now in flock on one Web site | first=Bob | last=Hoover | newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | location=Pittsburgh, PA | date=4 March 2008 | accessdate=22 August 2011}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/art-architecture/2017/11/14/John-James-Audubon-falcons-birds-of-prey-National-Aviary-Hillman-Library/stories/201711150043|title=Free Audubon Day includes prints, lectures|work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|access-date=29 November 2017|language=en}} This event, called "Audubon day" was first conducted in 2011.{{Cite web|url=http://www.news.pitt.edu/Audubon_Day_2012|title=Pitt’s University Library System Hosts Second Annual Audubon Day|publisher= University of Pittsburgh News|website=www.news.pitt.edu|language=en|access-date=29 November 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://pittnews.com/article/64902/news/birders-flock-to-audubons-art/|title=Birders flock to Audubon's art - The Pitt News|date=2 November 2015|work=The Pitt News|access-date=29 November 2017|language=en-US}} In 2007 the book was the subject of an exhibition by the [[Teylers Museum]] in [[Haarlem]], which owns a copy it ordered from the original subscription.{{cite web|url=http://www.vogelsxxl.nl/tentoonstelling.php|title=Teyler's 2007 exhibition website|date=3 November 2007|publisher=Vogelsxxl.nl|accessdate=10 December 2010}} To commemorate the book's record-breaking sale, the museum decided to display its copy (for which the museum eventually paid 2200 [[guilder]]s—a fortune at the time—during the years 1827–1838) until January 2011.{{Citation needed|date=November 2017}} All of Audubon's and Mason's known extant watercolors preparatory for ''Birds of America'' are housed at the [[New-York Historical Society]] in New York City.{{cite web|url=http://www.minniesland.com/study_Audubon_Art_Prints_Steiner.htm|title=Original Audubon Prints - Antique Natural History Prints - Books - Havell - Bien - Imperial Folio - Bird and Animal Prints|work=minniesland.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101111025136/http://www.minniesland.com/study_Audubon_Art_Prints_Steiner.htm|archivedate=11 November 2010|df=dmy-all}} The [[Stark Museum of Art]] in [[Orange, Texas]] owns and exhibits John James Audubon's personal copy of ''Birds of America''.{{cite web |url=http://kogt.com/Stark%20Audubon.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101216212421/http://kogt.com/Stark%20Audubon.htm |archivedate=16 December 2010 |df=dmy-all }} In 2010 the [[North Carolina Museum of Art]] began a five-year exhibition of its restored four-volume set purchased for the state by Governor [[William Alexander Graham]] in 1846.{{cite web|url=http://www.ncartmuseum.org/exhibitions/audubon|title=Exhibitions|work=ncartmuseum.org}} [[Liverpool Central Library]] currently has a copy of ''Birds of America'' on display in a glass case, with its pages turned weekly,{{cite web|url=http://www.sevenstreets.com/city-living/refurbishment-liverpool-central-library/ |title=Rekindling Liverpool Central Library |publisher=Sevenstreets.com |accessdate=24 January 2013}} as well as being displayed through an [[interactive kiosk]], allowing readers to view the contents close-up without damaging the original copy using an Evoke Ev5 Kiosk.{{cite web|url=http://www.evoke-kiosks.co.uk/news/the-book-and-the-kiosk.aspx|title=The book and the kiosk|work=evoke-kiosks.co.uk}} One of the original books was bought by [[Laurance Spelman Rockefeller]], who had each plate individually framed. They are all hanging throughout the public areas of the Woodstock Inn, in Woodstock, Vermont, which he built in 1969.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} Paisley Museum and Art Gallery, in [[Paisley, Renfrewshire|Paisley]] Scotland has the four volume elephant folio of Birds of America.{{Cite web|title = Prize possessions on show at Paisley museum|url = http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/prize-possessions-show-paisley-museum-6819388|website = dailyrecord|accessdate = 3 December 2015}} The [[Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Glasgow|Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons]] in Glasgow, Scotland holds one volume which is on display in the library, together with an interactive version.{{Cite web|title = Doors Open Day 2015|url = http://libraryblog.rcpsg.ac.uk/2015/08/28/doors-open-day-2015/|website = College Library|accessdate = 3 December 2015}} ==Collections and archives== Though individual prints are commonly available, only one hundred twenty complete sets are known to exist. One complete copy of ''The Birds of America'' exists as part of [[The Darlington Collection]] at the [[University of Pittsburgh]].{{cite web|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/art-architecture/2013/11/17/University-of-Pittsburgh-exhibits-Audubon-prints/stories/201311170047|title=Pitt exhibits Audubon prints|publisher=Pittsburgh Post Gazette|last=Pitz |first=Marylynne |date= 16 November 2013|access-date= 27 November 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://audubon.pitt.edu/|title=Audubon's Birds of America at the University of Pittsburgh|website=audubon.pitt.edu|access-date=27 November 2017}} Another complete collection is housed with [[Meisei University]] in Tokyo, Japan.{{Cite web|url=http://birdsofamerica.meisei-u.ac.jp/|title=Meisei University Birds Of America, Meisei University|last=|first=|date=|website=birdsofamerica.meisei-u.ac.jp|access-date=27 November 2017}} ''The Birds of America'' is on permanent display in [[Trinity College (Connecticut)|Trinity College's]] Watkinson Library, and was owned by the engraver, Robert Havell. It was donated to the College in 1900 by Gurdon Wadsworth Russell, an 1834 graduate of Trinity.{{Cite web|url=http://www.trincoll.edu/NewsEvents/NewsArticles/pages/Birds.aspx|title=Trinity College is Nest for Birders|last=Webmaster|website=www.trincoll.edu|access-date=1 October 2016}} [[Toronto Public Library]] also holds a copy; originally a four-volume set, it was unbound to preserve the individual plates which have been digitized in the library’s [https://www.torontopubliclibrary.ca/search.jsp?Erp=20&N=38537+4294831200&Ntt=Audubon&view=grid Digital Archive] and stored in custom-made boxes in the Toronto Reference Library.{{Cite web|url=http://omeka.tplcs.ca/virtual-exhibits/exhibits/show/audubon/tpl-copy|title=Birds of America at the Toronto Public Library · John J. Audubon’s Birds of America · TPL Virtual Exhibits|website=omeka.tplcs.ca|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-11}} Another complete copy of the prints, bound in 17 volumes, belongs to the [[Library of Parliament]] in [[Ottawa]], Canada.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/john-james-audubon-birds-library-parliament-digitize-1.3838474|title=Library of Parliament digitized John James Audubon bird masterpiece {{!}} CBC News|work=CBC|access-date=2018-10-26|language=en-US}} ==Recent sales== In March 2000 Sheikh [[Collecting practices of the Al-Thani Family|Saud Al-Thani of Qatar purchased]] a copy of ''The Birds of America'' at a [[Christie's]] auction for $8.8 million, a record for any book at auction.{{cite web|url=http://www.artandantiquesmag.com/2009/02/call-of-the-wild/|title=John James Audubon's 'Birds Of America' Sells for $8.8 Million|work=Art & Antiques Magazine}} In December 2010, ''[[The Economist]]'' magazine estimated that, adjusted for inflation, five of the ten highest prices ever paid for printed books were paid for copies of ''The Birds of America''.{{cite news| url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/dailychart/2010/12/books | work=The Economist | title=Book value | date=8 December 2010}} Of the 120 copies known to survive, only thirteen are held in private collections.{{cite web|last=Collett |first=Mike |url=http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/40547140 |title=Rare 'Birds of America' book fetches $11.5M at auction|publisher=Today.msnbc.msn.com |date= |accessdate=10 December 2010}} In March 2000 the Fox-Bute copy sold at Christie's, New York, for $8,802,500.[[BBC]], 9 September 2010, [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-11242275 World's most expensive book goes back on sale]{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/shakespeare-first-edition-breaks-sothebys-record-with-16328m-sale-407861.html|title=Shakespeare first edition breaks Sotheby's record with £2.8m salet|work=The Independent}} In December 2005 an unbound copy, the Providence Athenaeum Set, sold, again at Christie's, New York, for $5.6 million.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704635704575604751410902906|title=Collectors Circle as 'Birds of America' Comes to Auction at Sotheby's|author=Ellen Gamerman|date=26 November 2010|work=Wall Street Journal}} On 6 December 2010, a complete copy of the first edition was sold in London at [[Sotheby's]] for £7,321,250 (approximately $11.5 million){{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-12-07/aristocrats-seeking-cash-boost-119-million-old-master-auctions-in-london.html | work=Bloomberg | first=Scott | last=Reyburn | title=‘Birds of America' Book Fetches Record $11.5 Million | date=7 December 2010}} during the sale of Magnificent Books, Manuscripts and Drawings from the Collection of Frederick, [[Frederick Fermor-Hesketh, 2nd Baron Hesketh|Second Lord Hesketh]]. The winning bid was a record auction price for a printed book and was placed by London-based art dealer [[Edward Tollemache#Courtier|Michael Tollemache]], who outbid three others during the auction. According to the [[provenance]] details reported by the auction house, the copy's original owner was [[Henry Witham]] of Durham, listed as subscriber 11 in Audubon's ''Ornithological Biography''; the first volume of the set bears a presentation inscription from Witham's wife, dated 24 June 1831.{{cite web| publisher= [[Sotheby's]] |url= http://www.sothebys.com/en/auctions/2010/magnificent-books-manuscripts-and-drawings-from-the-collection-of-frederick-2nd-lord-hesketh-l10413/overview.html| title= Lot 50: The Birds of America; from original drawings by John James Audubon. London: published by the author, 1827–1838 | accessdate=10 December 2010}} Lord Hesketh had bought the copy from a descendant of Witham at a [[Christie's]] auction on 3 July 1951, paying £7,000. On 20 January 2012 a complete copy of the first edition was sold by heirs of the [[William Bentinck, 4th Duke of Portland|Fourth Duke of Portland]] at Christie's, New York, for $7.9 million. The buyer was identified only as "an American collector who bid by phone." The sale brought to 120 the number of copies known to have survived – 107 in institution collections and 13 in private hands.{{cite news |title=Audubon's ‘Birds' sells for $7.9M |agency=Associated Press |url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2012-01-20/news/30649241_1_species-first-edition-audubon |newspaper=New York Daily News |date=20 January 2012 |accessdate=1 May 2012}} ==Plates== File:61 Great Horned Owl.jpg|Great horned owl
([[Great horned owl|''Bubo virginianus'']]) File:86 Black Warrior.jpg|Harlan's hawk in plate 86 File:11 Bird of Washington.jpg|Bird of Washington, possibly a rare species or a misidentified juvenile [[Bald eagle]] File:151 Turkey Buzzard.jpg|

 [[c:User:Mturtle/The_Birds_of_America|Gallery of the rest of the plates.]] ==Textiles== [[File:Audubon fabric.jpg|thumb|Furnishing fabric, from [[Lancashire]], 1830s]] In 1830s, immediately after the publication, several plates were used as a basis for the design of a series of roller-printed furnishing fabric, produced in [[Lancashire]], United Kingdom.{{cite web|title=Furnishing fabric, Lancashire, 1830s, Victoria and Albert Museum, CIRC.305-1956|url=https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O115037/furnishing-fabric/|accessdate=23 February 2012}} ==See also== * [[List of most expensive books and manuscripts]] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em|refs={{cite web| url= http://lccn.loc.gov/06018534 | title= The birds of America; from original drawings | publisher= [[Library of Congress]] | accessdate= 10 December 2010}} }} ==Bibliography== * Rhodes, Richard (2004). ''John James Audubon: The Making of an American''. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. {{ISBN|0-375-41412-6}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [http://audubon.pitt.edu ''Birds of America'' at the University of Pittsburgh] — ''with high resolution images of all 435 double elephant folios.'' * [http://birdsofamerica.meisei-u.ac.jp/ Meisei University: ''Birds of America''] — ''the complete sets of 435 plates of drawings, with the accompanying five volumes of textbooks.'' * {{Internet Archive short film|id=gov.archives.arc.55178|name=John James Audubon: The Birds of America (1986)}} *[https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Popular_Science_Monthly/Volume_31/September_1887/Sketch_of_J._J._Audubon Popular Science Monthly/Volume 31/September 1887/Sketch of J. revision.text:
{{Judaism}} The '''Three Pilgrimage Festivals''', in [[Hebrew]] '''''Shalosh Regalim''''' (שלוש רגלים), are three major festivals in [[Judaism]]—[[Pesach]] (''Passover''), [[Shavuot]] (''Weeks'' or ''Pentecost''), and [[Sukkot]] (''Tabernacles'', ''Tents'' or ''Booths'')—when the ancient [[Israelite]]s living in the [[Kingdom of Judah]] would make a [[pilgrimage]] to the [[Temple in Jerusalem]], as commanded by the [[Torah]]. In Jerusalem, they would participate in festivities and ritual worship in conjunction with the services of the [[Kohen|kohanim]] ("priests") at the Temple.
After the [[destruction of the Second Temple]] and until the building of the [[Third Temple]], the actual pilgrimages are no longer obligatory upon Jews, and no longer take place on a national scale. During [[synagogue]] [[Jewish services|services]] the related passages describing the holiday being observed are read aloud from a [[Torah scroll]] on the [[Bema#Judaism|bimah]] (platform) used at the center of the synagogue services. During the [[Jewish holiday]]s in modern-day Israel, many Jews living in or near Jerusalem make an effort to attend prayer services at the [[Western Wall]] emulating the ancient pilgrimages in some small fashion. [[Samaritans]] make pilgrimages to [[Mount Gerizim]] three times a year to this day.
==Sources in the Hebrew Bible== [[File:Thank offering unto the Lord.jpg|thumb|200px|Offering of the first fruits, illustration from a Bible card]] * [[Book of Exodus]] ({{em|emphasis added}}): "Offer a sacrifice to Me {{em|three times each year}}. Keep the festival of [[matzo]]s [unleavened bread] ... the reaping festival [i.e., ''Shavuot''] ... the harvest festival [i.e., ''Sukkot''].... {{em|Three times each year}}, every male among you must appear before God the Lord...." (Exodus 23:14–17) <ref>[http://bible.ort.org/books/pentd2.asp?ACTION=displaypage&BOOK=2&CHAPTER=23 Exodus 23]</ref> and "Keep the Festival of Matzahs [i.e., Passover].... Keep the Festival of ''Shavuot'' through the first fruits of your wheat harvest. Also keep the harvest festival [i.e., ''Sukkot''] soon after the year changes. {{em|Three times each year}}, all your males shall thus present themselves before God the Master, Lord of Israel." (Exodus 34:18-23) <ref>[http://bible.ort.org/books/pentd2.asp?ACTION=displaypage&BOOK=2&CHAPTER=34 Exodus 34]</ref> * [[Book of Deuteronomy]]: "Safeguard the month of standing grain so that you will be able to keep the [[Passover]] to God your Lord, since it was in the month of standing grain that God your Lord brought you out of Egypt at night.... Then count seven weeks for yourself. From the time that you first put the sickle to the standing grain, you must count seven weeks. You shall then celebrate the festival of [[Shavuot]] to God your Lord, presenting a hand-delivered offering according to the extent of the blessing that God your Lord has granted you.... When you bring in the products of your [[threshing floor]] and wine vat, you shall celebrate the festival of [[Sukkot]] for seven days.... {{em|Three times each year}}, all your males shall thus be seen in the presence of God your Lord in the place that He will choose: on the festival of matzahs, on the festival of Shavuot, and on the festival of Sukkot. You shall not appear before God empty-handed." (Deuteronomy 16:1, 9-10, 13, 16-17) <ref>[http://bible.ort.org/books/pentd2.asp?ACTION=displaypage&BOOK=5&CHAPTER=16 Deuteronomy 16]</ref>
==Other biblical references== In his vision of a restored Jerusalem, the prophet [[Isaiah]] refers to [[Zion]] as "the city of our appointed feasts".<ref>{{bibleverse||Isaiah|33:20|NKJV}}</ref> The [[Songs of Ascent]] or pilgrim psalms ([[Book of psalms|Psalms]] 120-134) are associated with the pilgrims' journey to Jerusalem.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Hossfeld |first1=Frank-Lothar|last2=Zenger|first2=Erich |date=2011 |title=Psalms 3: A Commentary on Psalms 101-150 |url= |location=Minneapolis |publisher=Fortress Press |pages=293–294 |isbn=978-0800607623 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Jewish holiday]]s
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Jewish holy days]] [[Category:Jewish pilgrimages]] [[Category:Seasonal holidays]] [[Category:Three Pilgrimage Festivals| ]]

The island country of [[Bermuda]] has been affected by several [[tornado]]es and [[waterspout]]s in its history.
== December 1925 tornado == In the early hours of December 12, 1925 a weak tornado affected [[Ireland Island, Bermuda|Ireland Island]]. Beginning as a waterspout, it moved into the Ireland Island Dock Yard. The ''Ormonde'', a ship docked there, was nearly capsized, and the ship's [[barometer]] recorded an instantaneous drop of 4 [[millibar|mb]]. Moving onto land as a tornado, the vortex damaged roofs, sheds, and fences as it tore across the island. An office in the ship yard which contained another [[weather station]] was also struck—the barometer there recorded a drop of 6 mb. The damage path was approximately 300 yards across.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/054/mwr-054-10-0428b.pdf| title = An Early Morning Tornado at Bermuda| accessdate = 2006-11-10| author = Unknown|date=October 1926| format = PDF| work = [[Monthly Weather Review]]| publisher = [[American Meteorological Society]]| pages = 428}}</ref>
== Easter tornadoes of 1953 == Four tornadoes caused major damage on April 5, 1953. One person was killed by flying [[debris]].<ref>{{cite journal | doi=10.1080/00431672.1953.9932943 | author=Macky, W. A| title=The Easter Tornadoes at Bermuda| journal=Weatherwise| volume=6 | issue=3 |date=June 1953| pages=74–75}}</ref>
== January 1986 tornadoes == On January 12, 1986, two tornadoes struck the north and south shores of the Main Island. The first one, which touched down near [[Devonshire, Bermuda|Devonshire]], caused significant damage as it cut across the island. The second tornado affected [[St. David's, Bermuda|St. David's]], on the north shore, less than two hours later. Several boats were sunk by the two twisters as they moved over water.<ref>{{cite web| url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A0DE6DD1131F931A25752C0A960948260| title = Tornadoes in Bermuda Tear Roofs Off Homes| accessdate = 2006-11-10| author = Associated Press| authorlink = Associated Press| date = 1986-01-12| work = [[New York Times]]}}</ref>
== Hurricane Emily September 1987 == On September 25, 1987 [[Hurricane Emily (1987)| Hurricane Emily]] made landfall in Bermuda as a category one hurricane on the [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale]]. The fast moving hurricane was associated with several damaging tornadoes.<ref>http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1987-prelim/emily/prelim04.gif</ref>
== March 1992 == On March 21, 1992 U.S. Naval Oceanography Command Facility later confirmed a tornado struck the east end of the island, damaging the Naval Air Station.<ref name="royalgazette.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/19930422/NEWS/304229973|title=Tornadoes: the telltale signs - The Royal Gazette:Bermuda News|website=royalgazette.com|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref> Damaged houses in St. David's remained in need some time later and Government assistance was arranged.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/19920505/NEWS/305059972|title=Sixteen St. David's households still needy - The Royal Gazette:Bermuda News|website=royalgazette.com|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref>
== February 1993 == Damaging winds, possibly related to tornadic activity impacted the island early in the morning on February 19th 1993. The storms effects were felt hardest in Sandy's Parish and along North Shore. One person was injured and 100 customers lost electricity in the storms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/19930220/NEWS/302209992|title=Island pounded by fierce freak storm - The Royal Gazette:Bermuda News|website=royalgazette.com|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref>
== April 1993 == On April 15, 1993 U.S. Naval Oceanography Command Facility confirmed a tornado struck the west end causing "major damage" before dissipating over the Great Sound.<ref name="royalgazette.com"/> This tornado was followed by heavy rains.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/19930422/NEWS/304229981|title=More rain likely - The Royal Gazette:Bermuda News|website=royalgazette.com|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/19930416/NEWS/304169997|title=Another escape - The Royal Gazette:Bermuda News|website=royalgazette.com|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref> Damage was reportedly done to 25 homes in the Somerset area and Government prepared to offer assistance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/19930415/NEWS/304159990|title=Gov't offers helping hand to west end Tornado victims - The Royal Gazette:Bermuda News|website=royalgazette.com|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref> The severe thunderstorm responsible for this tornado also produced at least "marble sized hail" that covered the ground in spots. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/19930414/NEWS/304149975|title=West End homes hit by Tornado - The Royal Gazette:Bermuda News|website=royalgazette.com|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref>
== March 1999 == There were several reports of tornadoes on March 4, 1999. One tornado was spotted offshore and another was spotted later in the day coming ashore in Smith's parish damaging a construction site and two homes. Bermuda Weather Service did not make a conclusion on whether this was a tornado.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/19990305/NEWS/303059976|title=Suspected tornado rips through Smith's - The Royal Gazette:Bermuda News|website=royalgazette.com|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref>
== April 2000 == A reported tornado damaged Spice Valley high school as it struck in the evening on April 27 2000. The Bermuda Weather Service meteorologists indicated active thunderstorms in the area possibly produced an isolated tornado.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20000428/NEWS/304289982|title=Island - The Royal Gazette:Bermuda News|website=royalgazette.com|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref>
== December 2002 == December 14, 2002 saw nighttime tornadoes strike south shore, hitting hotels particularly hard in Southampton parish where $100,000 in property damage was done.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20021217/NEWS/312179979|title=South Shore hotels count costs of 'tornado' cleanup - The Royal Gazette:Bermuda News|website=royalgazette.com|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref> The Bermuda Weather Service suggested this could have been a small tornado.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20021216/NEWS/312169992|title=Freak tornado tears through South Shore - The Royal Gazette:Bermuda News|website=royalgazette.com|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref>
== Hurricane Fabian September 2003 == Several unconfirmed reports of tornadoes spawned by [[Hurricane Fabian]] as it made a direct-hit on the island on September 5, 2003. One such possible tornado severely damaged St. George's Preparatory school. It was impossible to discern tornado damage from hurricane damage and so these reported tornadoes went unconfirmed.
== January 2004 == Weekend severe weather on the morning of January 10, 2004 included reports of tornadoes striking parts of Pembroke, Hamilton, Southampton and Warwick parishes. Damage was reported at the local Saltus Grammar School and nearby neighborhoods in Pembroke where the Bermuda Weather Service confirmed a tornado struck.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20040112/NEWS/301129992|title=It was like a freight train coming through' - The Royal Gazette:Bermuda News|website=royalgazette.com|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref>
== July 2005 == A 'freak storm' struck parts of Smith's parish at around 6:30am on July 16, 2005 causing some roof damage. While residents were convinced it was a tornado, and Bermuda Weather Service radar suggested severe weather in the area, they could not conclusively say whether this was tornado damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20050118/NEWS/301189984|title=Storm causes damage in Smith's - The Royal Gazette:Bermuda News|website=royalgazette.com|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref>
== November 2005 == A reported tornado ripped the roofs off several homes in Sandy's parish on the afternoon of November 2, 2005. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20051103/NEWS/311039976|title=Winds of terror - The Royal Gazette:Bermuda News|website=royalgazette.com|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref> A later investigation by the Bermuda Weather Service suggested this was the work of a gustnado with gusts up to 80kts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20051104/NEWS/311049965|title=Tornado in Sandys? Try gustnado, says expert - The Royal Gazette:Bermuda News|website=royalgazette.com|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref>
== Hurricane Florence September 2006== Unconfirmed reports of tornado damage well in advance of [[Hurricane Florence (2006)|Hurricane Florence]] in Southampton as the outer bands of the hurricane spiraled across the island on the afternoon of September 10th, 2006.
== December 2009 == On December 19th, 2009, a tornado touched down in downtown Hamilton, Pembroke parish. It created a swath of damage from Pitt's Bay road to First Avenue in the Cavendish Heights area of Pembroke. Hardest hit areas included the commercial areas of Reid Street from Queen Street to Court Street, and parts of Bermudiana Road. Automated recording stations on Hinson's Island reported a wind gust of {{convert|64|kn|mph km/h}}. Although there were no reports of serious injuries, there was significant tree and roof damage, and the tornado was estimated to be an EF1 or EF2 on the [[Enhanced Fujita Scale]]. There were other reports of tornadoes that turned out to be straight line winds from severe thunderstorms at Devonshire Bay, where trees were snapped and a fence was reported to have been knocked over. <ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.weather.bm/DownloadsAndPresentations/19Dec2009_TornadoReport_webversion.pdf| title = Report on Tornado & Severe Thunderstorm 19, December 2009| accessdate = 2010-04-02| author = BWS| date = December 2009| format = PDF| publisher = [[Bermuda Weather Service]]| pages = 1–7| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110706151602/http://www.weather.bm/DownloadsAndPresentations/19Dec2009_TornadoReport_webversion.pdf| archivedate = 2011-07-06| df = }}</ref>
== Hurricane Sandy October 2012 == On October 28, 2012, showers associated with the outermost circulation of a distant [[Hurricane Sandy]] were affecting the island. One of these showers briefly produced a tornado that resulted in roof damage and boundary wall damage to structures in Somerset Village in Sandy's Parish. The Bermuda Weather Service rated the tornado an F-0 on the [[Fujita Scale]].<ref>{{cite web| url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL182012_Sandy}}| title = Tropical Cyclone Report Hurricane Sandy| accessdate = 3 January 2015 | author = Eric S. Blake, Todd B. Kimberlain, Robert J. Berg, John P. Cangialosi and John L. Beven II| publisher = National Hurricane Center| page = 14}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Tornadoes in Bermuda]] [[Category:Tornado-related lists|Bermuda]]
